Description: An online appliance retailer agreed to pay a $100,000 penalty to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it failed to post required EnergyGuide information on its websites to inform consumers about the energy use of major home appliances it sold.

Universal Processing Services of Wisconsin, LLC, a payment processor, and telemarketer Hal E. Smith and his company HES Merchant Services Company, Inc., defendants in the Federal Trade Commission's case against a deceptive robocall credit card interest rate reduction scheme, were jointly ordered to pay $1,734,972 to the Commission by a Florida district court. The money was to be used to provide refunds to defrauded consumers.

Description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ordered U.S. Bank to provide an estimated $48 million in relief to consumers harmed by what it called illegal billing practices. U.S. Bank was also required to pay a $5 million civil money penalty to the CFPB.

The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development announced that U.S. Bank National Association agreed to pay $12,000 to a loan applicant with disabilities under a Conciliation Agreement settling allegations that the bank required him to provide unnecessary documentation to establish he would continue receiving disability income for three years before they would approve his mortgage loan.

The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development announced that it has reached an agreement with U.S. Bank National Association and its subsidiary Red Sky Risk Services, LLC resolving allegations that they refused to refinance the mortgage of a Native American couple in Belcourt, North Dakota, because their property is located on a reservation.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau put an end to what it called a servicemember fee scam run by USA Discounters, Ltd., a company that operated a chain of retail stores near military bases and offered financing for purchases. The CFPB obtained more than $350,000 in refunds for servicemembers and ordered USA Discounters to pay an additional $50,000 civil penalty.

ValueVision International, Inc., a home shopping retailer, agreed to pay a $215,000 civil penalty to resolve allegations that it violated a previous Federal Trade Commission order by making unsubstantiated health claims for Physician's RX, a dietary supplement.

Description: Vending Communications, Inc., Interactive Communication Services, Inc., and their president agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that they misrepresented the earnings that prospective purchasers of their business opportunities could realize.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau filed proposed orders in federal courts against Sprint and Verizon which, if approved, would provide $120 million in redress to wireless customers said to have been illegally billed hundreds of millions of dollars in unauthorized third-party charges. The CFPB alleges that the companies operated billing systems that allowed third parties to "cram" unauthorized charges on customers' mobile-phone accounts and ignored complaints about the charges.

The Federal Communications Commission's Enforcement Bureau reached a $7.4 million settlement with Verizon to resolve an investigation into the company's use of personal consumer information for marketing purposes. The Enforcement Bureau's investigation uncovered that Verizon failed to notify approximately two million new customers, on their first invoices or in welcome letters, of their privacy rights, including how to opt out from having their personal information used in marketing campaigns, before the company accessed their personal information to market services to them.

Verizon agreed to a $3.4 million settlement to resolve a Federal Communications Commission investigation into the company's failure to meet its emergency call obligations during a multistate 911 service in 2014.

The Federal Communications Commission entered into a Consent Decree with the Verizon Telephone Companies in which Verizon admitted that it violated a federal ban on marketing long distance services in its local service region prior to receiving FCC authorization.

The Federal Communications Commission's Enforcement Bureau announced that Verizon Wireless agreed to pay $90  million and Sprint Corporation agreed to pay $68 million to settle investigations that revealed the companies billed customers millions of dollars in unauthorized third-party premium text messaging services, a practice called cramming.

The Federal Communications Commission's Enforcement Bureau announced an historic consent decree with Verizon Wireless -- including a record $25 million payment to the U.S. Treasury -- regarding "mystery fees" the company charged its customers over the last several years. In addition to Verizon Wireless's payment to the Treasury, the company agreed to refund a minimum of $52.8 million to approximately 15 million customers and ensure that consumers are no longer charged the fees.

The Federal Communications Commission announced a settlement resolving an investigation into Verizon Wireless's practice of inserting unique identifier headers or so-called supercookies into its customers' mobile Internet traffic without their knowledge or consent.

The FCC's Enforcement Bureau released a $1.25 million consent decree with Verizon Wireless that resolved an investigation into whether the company had fully complied with the FCC's rules requiring licensees of C Block spectrum to allow customers to freely use the devices and applications of their choosing.

The Federal Trade Commission, with the assistance of the U.S. Department of Justice, settled a complaint against a Massachusetts-based home security company that illegally called millions of consumers on the FTC's National Do Not Call (DNC) Registry to pitch home security systems.

Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Description: Adopted a Consent Decree with Viacom Inc. and certain of its subsidiaries to resolve indecency investigations involving Viacom broadcast stations, as well as non-Viacom owned affiliates of CBS and UPN.

Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Description: Viatek Consumer Products Group, Inc. and company owner and President Lou Lentine agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they made deceptive claims for Viatek-brand Mosquito Shield Bands. The Commission also charged Lentine and Viatek with violating a 2003 administrative order prohibiting Lentine from making product claims without competent and reliable evidence to back them up.

Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Company: Viking Range, LLC and Middleby Corporation
Description: Viking Range, LLC, of Greenwood, Mississippi, and its parent firm, The Middleby Corporation, agreed to pay a $4.65 million civil penalty to settle allegations that Viking failed to immediately report to CPSC that its gas ranges contained a defect that could create a substantial product hazard or that the ranges created an unreasonable risk of serious injury.

Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Description: The Justice Department announced an agreement with Vincent Porcaro Inc. resolving allegations that the company violated the anti-discrimination provision of the Immigration and Nationality Act.

Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division
Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division
Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division
Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division
Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division
Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division
Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division
Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division
Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Description: A U.S. District Court ordered the operators of several international tech support scams to pay more than $5.1 million, acting on Federal Trade Commission charges that they masqueraded as major computer companies, tricked consumers into believing their computers were riddled with malware and then charged consumers to fix them.

Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division
Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Company: Vision Airlines, Inc., doing business as Vision Air
Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Description: Two authorized dealers of the satellite television provider Dish Network agreed to settle charges that they violated the FTC's Telemarketing Sales Rule by calling consumers whose numbers are on the Do Not Call Registry.

Company: Visions Group of America, Inc. and SOHO Technologies, Inc.
Description: Two companies and their principals that the Federal Trade Commission alleged used high-pressure sales tactics to sell various home-based business opportunities agreed to settle FTC accusations that they made false and unsubstantiated earnings claims to entice consumers to buy their products and violated the FTC's Cooling-Off Rule, which gives consumers three days to cancel certain purchases of $25 or more.

Two Maine-based dietary supplement marketers and their principals have agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they made deceptive advertising claims about their dietary supplement products, in violation of federal law.

Marketers of Focus Factor, a dietary supplement that purported to improve concentration, and V-Factor, a supplement that purported to enhance sexual performance, agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that they made numerous unsubstantiated advertising claims for the products.

VIZIO, Inc., one of the Largest manufacturers and sellers of internet-connected smart televisions, agreed to pay $2.2 million to allegations by the Federal Trade Commission and the Office of the New Jersey Attorney General that it installed software on its TVs to collect viewing data on 11 million consumer TVs without consumers' knowledge or consent.

Vocational Guides, Inc. and its president were permanently banned from promoting or selling employment services, and were required to pay approximately $191,600 in disgorgement and consumer redress as part of a settlement of Federal Trade Commission allegations that they engaged in the fraudulent sale of employment services.

The Federal Trade Commission announced a complaint and proposed consent decree settling charges that a California-based voice broadcaster made over 46 million unlawful telemarketing calls. The proposed court order permanently barred the defendants from violating the FTC's Telemarketing Sales Rule and required them to pay $180,000 in civil penalties.

A deceptive robocall operation that allegedly used millions of pre-recorded telemarketing messages to fraudulently pitch extended auto warranties to U.S. consumers agreed to pay more than $655,000 in consumer redress and were permanently banned from telemarketing, as part of a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission.

Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Company: VRG Linhas Aereas S.A. d/b/a GOL Linhas Aereas Inteligentes
Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Company: W3 Innovations, LLC dba Broken Thumbs Apps
Description: A developer of mobile applications, including children's games for the iPhone and iPod touch, agreed to pay $50,000 to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it violated the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) and the FTC's COPPA Rule by illegally collecting and disclosing personal information from tens of thousands of children under age 13 without their parents' prior consent.

Following a public comment period, the Federal Trade Commission has approved two final orders settling charges that two companies, Norm Thompson Outfitters. Inc., and Wacoal America, Inc., misled consumers regarding the ability of their caffeine-infused shapewear undergarments to reshape the wearer's body and reduce cellulite.

National pharmacy chain Walgreens agreed to pay nearly $6 million to settle FTC charges that the company deceptively advertised Wal-Born, a line of dietary supplements similar to the Airborne cold-and-flu treatment,  using the same kind of baseless claims that the supplements could prevent colds, fight germs, and boost the immune system.

The Justice Department announced a $1.25 million agreement with Warren Properties Inc., Warren Village (Mobile) Limited Partnership and Frank R. Warren to settle allegations that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act by refusing to grant a tenant's requests for a reasonable accommodation.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ordered Mortgage Master, Inc. and Washington Federal to pay civil penalties for violating the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA), which requires certain mortgage lenders to accurately collect and report data about home mortgage loans. Mortgage Master will pay $425,000 and Washington Federal will pay $34,000 in civil penalties.

Company: Washington Potato Company and Pasco Processing, LLC

Description: The Federal Communications Commission announced plants to fine WDBJ Television, Inc. of Roanoke, Virginia, $325,000 for broadcasting graphic and sexually explicit material during the station's evening newscast.

Company: We The People Forms and Service Centers USA, Inc.
Description: A company that sold legal document preparation franchises agreed to pay a $286,000 civil penalty to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that it violated federal law by failing to disclose lawsuits against it to prospective franchisees.

Operators who allegedly crammed unauthorized charges for website services onto the phone bills of hundreds of thousands of small businesses and non-profits agreed to pay more than $1.2 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that their operations violated federal law.

Weider Nutrition International, Inc., based in Salt Lake City, Utah, agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that it made unsubstantiated efficacy and safety claims in its advertisements for dietary supplement products.

A federal court has found that marketers of bogus remedies for treating and preventing diabetes violated Section 5 of the FTC Act, and has ordered them to pay nearly $2.2 million. The FTC will use the funds it recovers to reimburse consumers.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and the Maryland Attorney General took action against Wells Fargo and JPMorgan Chase for what was said to be an illegal marketing-services-kickback scheme they participated in with Genuine Title, a now-defunct title company. The proposed consent orders, filed in federal court, would require $24 million in civil penalties from Wells Fargo, $600,000 in civil penalties from JPMorgan Chase, and $11.1 million in redress to consumers whose loans were involved in this scheme.

The Justice Department announced a comprehensive settlement agreement under the Americans with Disabilities Act with Wells Fargo & Company to ensure equal access for individuals with disabilities to Wells Fargo's services nationwide, including its nearly 10,000 retail banking, brokerage and mortgage stores, over 12,000 ATMs, and its telephone and website services.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took action against Wells Fargo Bank for illegal private student loan servicing practices that increased costs and unfairly penalized certain student loan borrowers. The Bureau identified breakdowns throughout Wells Fargo's servicing process, including failing to provide important payment information to consumers, charging consumers illegal fees, and failing to update inaccurate credit report information. The CFPB's order required Wells Fargo to improve its consumer billing and student loan payment processing practices. The company was also ordered to provide $410,000 in relief to borrowers and pay a $3.6 million civil penalty to the CFPB.

Wells Fargo Bank N.A., doing business as Wells Fargo Dealer Services, agreed to change its policies and pay over $4.1 million to resolve allegations that it violated the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act (SCRA) by repossessing 413 cars owned by protected servicemembers without obtaining a court order.

The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development announced that it reached a $5 million settlement with Wells Fargo Home Mortgage resolving allegations that the lender discriminated against women who were pregnant, or had recently given birth, and were on maternity leave.
A leading debt collection company agreed to pay a civil penalty of $2.8 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that its aggressive collection techniques violated federal law.

To settle Federal Trade Commission allegations, West Coast Advertising & Marketing and its principals agreed to pay $90,000 and verify the accuracy of claims they made on behalf of nonprofits for whom they solicited funds.

Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Company: Westlake Services, LLC and Wilshire Consumer Credit, LLC
Description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau announced an enforcement action against an indirect auto finance company and its auto title lending subsidiary for pressuring borrowers using allegedly illegal debt collection tactics. The CFPB found that Westlake Services, LLC and Wilshire Consumer Credit, LLC deceived consumers by calling under false pretenses and using phony caller ID information, falsely threatened to refer borrowers for investigation or criminal prosecution, and illegally disclosed information about debts to borrowers' employers, friends, and family. The Bureau ordered the companies to overhaul their debt collection practices and to provide consumers $44.1 million in cash relief and balance reductions. The companies were also also to pay a civil penalty of $4.25 million.

A debt collection agency that allegedly used lies and threats to collect debts agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that its tactics violated federal laws. Under the court settlement, the company agreed to a $150,000 judgment and to refrain from illegal practices when collecting debts, including time-barred debts -- debts so old they are no longer legally enforceable.

Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development announced $1.95 million in settlements under The Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act (RESPA) with three major homebuilders that engaged in business practices involving captive title reinsurance.

Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development announced $1.6 million in settlements under The Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act (RESPA) with a national mortgage lender and two major homebuilders that engaged in business practices involving captive title reinsurance.

Company: Woodbridge Coins and Jewelry Exchange, Inc.
Description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and the Attorney General of Virginia took action against Woodbridge Coins and Jewelry Exchange, Inc., doing business as Woodbridge Gold & Pawn, for deceiving consumers about the actual annual costs of its loans.

Educational services company WordSmart Corporation and its president agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they deceptively marketed the company's programs to the parents of school-age children in advertising that included a television infomercial featuring quiz show host Alex Trebek.

Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Company: World Interactive Gaming Corp. et al.
Description: Internet gambling casino developers charged with using deceptive claims to sell stock in their business agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that their practices violated federal laws.

Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Description: World Wide Coffee, Inc., based in Jupiter, Florida, and its agreed to settle FTC allegations that they failed to provide the pre-sale disclosures to prospective purchasers of their espresso coffee machine vending opportunities.

Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Description: Social networking website operator Xanga.com, Inc. and its principals agreed to pay a $1 million civil penalty for allegedly violating the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act.

Company: Y King S Corp. dba Herbies Auto Sales
Description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took action against Herbies Auto Sales, a buy-here pay-here used car dealer, for abusive financing schemes, hiding auto finance charges and misleading consumers. Herbies was required to pay $700,000 in restitution to harmed consumers, with a suspended civil penalty of $100,000.

Acting on a Federal Trade Commission complaint, a federal court has ordered a European-based operation to pay more than $10.2 million for tricking small businesses and nonprofit organizations into paying for unwanted listings in online business directories. The default judgment permanently bans the defendants from marketing Internet directories and listings in the future, and prohibits them from collecting payments from their previous customers, disclosing or otherwise benefitting from customers' personal information, and failing to dispose of this information properly.

Online review site Yelp, Inc., and mobile app developer TinyCo, Inc., agreed to settle separate Federal Trade Commission charges that they improperly collected children's information in violation of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act, or COPPA, Rule. Under the terms of the settlements, Yelp will pay a $450,000 civil penalty, while TinyCo will pay a $300,000 civil penalty.
The FTC announced that Yesmail agreed to pay a $50,717 penalty to resolve a case involving the sending of unsolicited commercial e-mail after consumers asked it to stop.

At the request of the Federal Trade Commission, a federal court entered a judgment of more than $3.6 million against a payment processor and its subsidiary that allegedly debited consumers' bank accounts illegally on behalf of deceptive telemarketers. According to a 2007 complaint filed by the FTC and seven states, Your Money Access, LLC and its subsidiary, YMA Company, LLC, processed unauthorized debits on behalf of deceptive telemarketers and Internet-based schemes that were violating the FTC's Telemarketing Sales Rule and state consumer protection laws.

The Justice Department announced that an order of permanent injunction against The Zaken Corp. of Thousand Oaks, California, and company president Tiran Zaken, of Calabasas, California, was entered by a federal judge, finding that they made false and misleading statements in marketing work-at-home business opportunities and promising commissions to consumers. The court ordered the defendants to pay $25,406,781 as redress for consumer injury.

The Federal Trade Commission announced that two investment funds, ESL Partners, L.P. and ZAM Holdings, L.P., agreed to settle allegations that they violated federal law by failing to make timely filings with the government prior to acquiring blocks of AutoZone, Inc. shares in September and October of 2004.

Zango, Inc., formerly known as 180solutions, Inc., a large distributor of adware, and two principals agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they used unfair and deceptive methods to download adware and obstruct consumers from removing it, in violation of federal law. The settlement barred future downloads of Zango's adware without consumers' consent, required Zango to provide a way for consumers to remove the adware, and required the company to give up $3 million in ill-gotten gains.
A federal judge issued a $5.5 million civil penalty against Zen Magnets LLC, a Colorado company, which illegally sold powerful small magnets that already had been recalled by another company.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took action against an online lead aggregator for steering consumers toward lenders who offered illegal or unlicensed loans that were void in the consumer's state.
The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau filed a proposed final judgment in federal court that would resolve a lawsuit against Prime Marketing Holdings, LLC for illegal credit repair practices.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took action against two American Express banking subsidiaries for discriminating against consumers in Puerto Rico, the U.S. Virgin Islands, and other U.S. territories by providing them with credit and charge card terms that were inferior to those available in the 50 states. American Express was also said to have discriminated against certain consumers with Spanish-language preferences.  American Express paid approximately $95 million in consumer redress during the course of the Bureau's review and American Express' review, and the order required it to pay at least another $1 million to fully compensate harmed consumers.
The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took action against JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. for failures related to information it provides for checking account screening reports.

The Consumer Product Safety Commission announced that Home Depot U.S.A. Inc. agreed to pay a $5.7 million civil penalty for selling and distributing previously recalled consumer products. The agreement settled allegations that the firm knowingly sold and distributed approximately 2,816 recalled products from 33 separate voluntary corrective actions during a four-year period from August 2012 through November 2016.

Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took action against real estate settlement services provider Meridian Title Corporation for steering consumers to a title insurer owned in part by several of its executives without making disclosures about the businesses' affiliation.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took action against Top Notch Funding and two individuals associated with the company for lying in loan offerings to consumers who were awaiting payment from settlements in legal cases or from victim-compensation funds.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took action against the National Collegiate Student Loan Trusts and their debt collector, Transworld Systems, Inc., for illegal student loan debt collection lawsuits.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took action against the National Collegiate Student Loan Trusts and their debt collector, Transworld Systems, Inc., for illegal student loan debt collection lawsuits.

Company: Wells Fargo Bank N.A., d/b/a Wells Fargo Dealer Services
Description: The Justice Department announcedthat it obtained an additional $5.4 million for servicemembers whose vehicles were unlawfully repossessed by Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. in violation of the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act (SCRA).  The bank, which does business under the name Wells Fargo Dealer Services,  agreed to pay this money to approximately 450 servicemembers under a 2016 settlement that resolved the department's SCRA lawsuit against the company. This additional amount brought the total compensation under the settlement to more than $10.1 million and the total number of servicemembers eligible for relief to more than 860.

Westlake Services LLC and its subsidiary Wilshire Consumer Capital LLC agreed to pay $760,788 to resolve allegations that the companies violated the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act by repossessing 70 vehicles owned by SCRA-protected servicemembers without first obtaining the required court orders.

CitiFinancial Credit Company, as successor to CitiFinancial Auto Corporation, agreed to pay $907,000 to resolve allegations that it violated the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act (SCRA) by repossessing 164 cars owned by SCRA protected servicemembers without first obtaining the required court orders.
Resolves an investigation into whether Radwin, Ltd. and Radwin, Inc. marketed radio frequency (RF) devices that did not comply with the Commission's equipment authorization requirements

The Federal Communications Commission entered into a Consent Decree with Verizon to resolve an investigation by the Enforcement Bureau's USF Strike Force into whether Verizon violated the rules of the E-rate program.

The Enforcement Bureau issued a Forfeiture Order imposing a $25,000 forfeiture against Public Safety Technologies, Inc., the licensee of Station WQJM334, for violating the Commission's Part 90 service rules.
This Notice of Apparent Liability for Forfeiture proposed a penalty of $3,963,722 against Neon Phone Service, Inc. for apparently slamming and cramming consumers.
Assesses a $13,000 forfeiture against Global Paratransit Inc. for failing to operate its PLMR station on a narrowband basis, failing to transmit its call sign, and failing to respond to an NOV.

A Southern California-based auto dealership group was required to pay $1.4 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it violated a 2014 administrative order prohibiting it from misrepresenting how much consumers could pay to finance or lease a vehicle.

An office supplier and its owner agreed to pay $7 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they tricked child care centers, schools, and police and fire departments into paying for products they never ordered.

Company: Life Care Center of Hickory Woods
ZB N.A. (fka Zions First National Bank)
Description: ZB, N.A, formerly known as Zions First National Bank, N.A., settled allegations that it and an affiliated payment processor facilitated consumer fraud by providing payment processing services to telemarketing and Internet merchants that were debiting money illegally from consumers' bank accounts.

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York

Description: Quad/Graphics Inc. agreed to pay $750,000 to the United States to resolve allegations that the firm violated security requirements involving personally identifiable information on contracts with the U.S. Government Publishing Office.

Kent State University agreed to pay $145,000 to settle a civil rights lawsuit alleging that the university had maintained a policy of not allowing students with psychological disabilities to keep emotional support animals in university-operated student housing.

Across Town Movers, a San Diego-based storage company, and its owner agreed to pay nearly $170,000 to resolve allegations by the Department of Justice that it unlawfully sold U.S. Navy service members' stored goods.

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Eastern District of New York

Description: A Springfield, Mo., company pleaded guilty in federal court to importing thousands of lamps from its manufacturer in China bearing counterfeit safety certification labels.

Description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took action against Citibank, N.A. for misleading borrowers into believing that they were not eligible for a valuable tax deduction on interest paid on certain student loans. The agency also alleged that the company incorrectly charged late fees and added interest to the student loan balances of borrowers who were still in school and eligible to defer their loan payments -- and that it misled consumers about how much they had to pay in their monthly bills and failed to disclose required information after denying borrowers' requests to release loan cosigners. The Bureau ordered Citibank to end these practices and to pay $3.75 million in redress to consumers and a $2.75 million civil money penalty.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took action against Xerox Business Services, LLC, now called Conduent Business Services, for software errors that led to incorrect consumer information about more than one million borrowers being sent to credit reporting agencies. The agency also accused the company of failing to notify all of its auto lender clients about known flaws in its software that led to the errors. The  consent order required Xerox to pay a $1.1 million civil penalty, explain its mistakes to its lender clients, and fix its faulty software.

The Federal Communications Commission proposed a $13,376,200 fine against Sinclair Broadcast Group for apparently failing to make required disclosures in connection with programming sponsored by a third party.
Penalty of $100,000 against UnityComm, LLC for failure to timely file Telecommunications Reporting Worksheets with the Universal Service Administrative Company.

Resolves an investigation into whether Lumenier Holdco LLC, formerly known as FPV Manuals LLC, marketed radio frequency devices that did not comply with the Commission's equipment authorization requirements.
The Enforcement Bureau proposes a penalty of $25,000 against Acuity Brands, Inc. for apparently marketing radio frequency devices that were not labeled in accordance with the Commission's rules.

InfoCision, Inc., an Akron, Ohio-based company that has made millions of calls to consumers nationwide on behalf of charitable organizations, agreed to pay a $250,000 civil penalty to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that its telemarketers misled consumers by falsely saying they were not calling to solicit contributions.
Settlement of the terms of a consent decree entered into by Straight Path for failure to deploy spectrum licenses; the licenses were later transferred to Verizon.

Company: Feature Films for Families, Inc.; Corporations for Character, L.C.; and Family Films of Utah
Repair All PC LLC et al.

tower registration

This settlement, which covered 3.0-liter diesel vehicles produced by VW, supplemented an early agreement concerning 2.0-liter cars. Both were outgrowths of allegations that the company cheated on emissions testing. In this case VW agreed to repurchase vehicles from customers at an estimated total cost of up to $4 billion. Bosch, which manufactured the device that enabled to cheating, was said to be making a contribution toward the cost of the buyback but no amount was cited in the announcement. Also see: https://www.ftc.gov/system/files/documents/cases/3227_ftc_30l_order_executed.pdf

The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency assessed a $20 million civil money penalty against Wells Fargo Bank, N.A., and ordered the bank to make restitution to servicemembers who were harmed by the bank's violations of the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act.
Agency: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency

Description: The Consumer Financial Protection announced a settlement with Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. in a coordinated action with the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC). The Bureau found that Wells Fargo violated the Consumer Financial Protection Act in the way it administered a mandatory insurance program related to its auto loans. The Bureau also found that Wells Fargo violated the CFPA in how it charged certain borrowers for mortgage interest rate-lock extensions. Under the terms of the consent orders, Wells Fargo was ordered to remediate harmed consumers and undertake certain activities related to its risk management and compliance management. The Bureau assessed a $1 billion penalty against the bank and credited the $500 million penalty collected by the OCC toward the satisfaction of its fine.

Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Description: The Federal Communications Commission reached a settlement concluding its investigation into whether T-Mobile USA, Inc. violated the Communications Act when it failed to correct ongoing problems with delivery of calls to rural consumers and whether it violated the FCC rule that prohibits providers from inserting false ring tones with respect to hundreds of millions of calls.  T-Mobile agreed to pay $40 million to the U.S. Treasury and entered into a compliance plan to prevent future violations.

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York

Description: A federal district court in the Western District of Missouri entered an Order effectuating a settlement between the CFPB and Richard Moseley, Sr., Richard Moseley, Jr., and 20 interrelated corporate entities controlled by Moseley, Sr. and Moseley, Jr., in the Bureau's lawsuit regarding the unlawful origination and servicing of short-term, small-dollar online loans to consumers nationwide.

The Bureau concluded that Citibank violated the Truth in Lending Act by failing to reevaluate and reduce the annual percentage rates (APRs) for approximately 1.75 million consumer credit card accounts consistent with regulatory requirements, and by failing to have reasonable written policies and procedures to conduct the APR reevaluations consistent with regulation.

Description: The Bureau found that the company engaged in unfair practices that violated the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 by failing to adjust in a timely manner principal balances of student loans made under the Federal Family Education Loan Program.

Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA)

Avant LLC, an online lending company, agreed to pay $3.85 million to settle allegations that it engaged in deceptive and unfair loan servicing practices, such as imposing unauthorized charges on consumers' accounts and unlawfully requiring consumers to consent to automatic payments from their bank accounts.

A Georgia-based distributor of water filtration systems agreed to pay a $110,000 civil penalty to settle allegations that it violated a 2017 Federal Trade Commission administrative order by making false claims that wholly imported Chinese water filtration systems were made in the United States.

At the Federal Trade Commission's request, a U.S. district court judge imposed a $2.7 million judgement and permanently halted what the FTC called an office supply scam operated by a business known as A-1 Janitorial. In late 2017, the FTC charged the defendants with targeting small businesses and charging them for supposedly free samples of cleaning and other products.

Thomas Wells and his payment processing company, Priority Payout Corp., agreed to settle FTC charges that they repeatedly violated a 2009 court order issued against them. The settlement permanently banned Wells and Priority Payout Corp. from engaging in, and assisting others with, payment processing, and included a $1.8 million contempt judgment against them.

A federal judge ordered journal publisher and conference organizer Srinubabu Gedela and his companies to pay more than $50.1 million to resolve Federal Trade Commission allegations that they made deceptive claims to academics and researchers about the nature of their conferences and publications, and hid steep publication fees.

Office Depot, Inc. and a California-based tech support software provider agreed to pay a total of $35 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that the companies tricked customers into buying millions of dollars' worth of computer repair and technical services by deceptively claiming their software had found malware symptoms on the customers' computers.

Office Depot, Inc. and a California-based tech support software provider agreed to pay a total of $35 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that the companies tricked customers into buying millions of dollars' worth of computer repair and technical services by deceptively claiming their software had found malware symptoms on the customers' computers.

Company: NetDotSolutions Inc. and TeraMESH Networks Inc.

The New York Attorney General announced settlements with seven online electronics stores located in New York to resolve allegation of engaging in a variety of illegal and fraudulent business practices. The seven companies agreed to pay a total of $665,000 in restitution and civil penalties, and over $100,000 to cover the costs of the Attorney General's investigation. The announcement did not specify how those amounts would be divided among the companies. Here we assume they were split evenly.

AmeriNet agreed to pay $50,000 to five states to settle litigation alleging that it processed debit charges from consumers' bank accounts on behalf of telemarketers who used allegedly fraudulent or unlawful scripts to pitch their products.

The RiverSource subsidiaries of Ameriprise agreed to pay $1.5 million to settle multistate litigation regarding the use of the Social Security Administration's Death Master File.

Amica agreed to pay over $800,000 in restitution, resolving allegations that it overcharged consumers for motorcycle insurance.
The owners and operators of Amir & Sanchez Nutraceuticals agreed to pay $175,000 in settlement of allegations of deceptive advertising techiques and unauthorized charges to customers.

The New York Attorney General announced an agreement with Arbitron, the second largest media ratings service, requiring the company to overhaul its system for determining radio ratings in New York in response to allegations that minority listeners were undercounted. Under the agreement, Arbitron was required to pay $260,000 to the state, make a contribution of $100,000 to the National Association of Black Owned Broadcasters and the Spanish Radio Association to support minority radio and fund an advertising campaign of at least $25,000 dedicated to promoting minority radio.

The California Attorney General announced a settlement with Arbitron Inc., the nation's dominant provider of radio audience ratings, over allegations that the method it used to collect ratings information discriminated against radio stations with predominantly African-American and Latino audiences.
Agreed to pay $25,000 in settlement of allegations its catalog and advertising were misleading by representing that all species of trees sold were genetically improved.

The New York Attorney General announced settlements with seven online electronics stores located in New York to resolve allegation of engaging in a variety of illegal and fraudulent business practices. As part of the settlement of allegations that it engaged in unfair and deceptive practices in connection with a 2017 data breach, Equifax agreed to provide $425 million in consumer relief and pay a $100 million civil penalty to the CFPB. It also paid $175 million to the states (see separate entry).

Equifax agreed to pay $175 million to 47 states as part of the settlement of claims stemming from a 2017 data breach that exposed the personal information of more than 147 million consumers. At the same time, Equifax agreed to create a consumer redress fund of at least $300 million and pay a $100 million civil penalty to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

Experian, TransUnion, and Equifax agreed to pay a total of $7.175 million to settle allegations they engaged in deceptive marketing activities by signing up customers to credit monitoring services they were unaware of, and also produced credit reports that failed to properly verify information and did not take into account Mississippi law. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among the three.

Equifax Information Services, Experian Information Solutions and TransUnion agreed to pay a total of $6 million to settle multistate allegations relating to their handling of consumer disputes about credit report errors, monitoring and disciplining data furnishers (providers of credit reporting information), accuracy in consumer credit reports, and the marketing of credit monitoring products to consumers who call the credit reporting agencies to dispute information on their credit report. The settlement did not specify how the $6 million cost would be split among the three companies; we assume each paid $2 million.

GBY Transmissions agreed to pay $50,000 in settlement of allegations of charging customers for auto repairs they didn't need.

GCC Alliance Concrete Inc. agreed to pay $145,000 in exchange for the state dropping a one-year ban on government business, and any further claims by the state over the company's earlier conviction. The company pleaded guilty to multiple conspiracies to fix prices in U.S.District Court, and under Iowa law, a contractor or supplier convicted of violating state or federal competition law is automatically disqualified from any work for a governmental agency for one year.
A state court ordered GE to pay $780,000 to customers and $650,000 in penalties to resolve a case involving allegations of a deceptive dishwasher recall.

Home Depot and the new owner of its banking partner GE Capital Corp. agreed to pay the state and customers a total of $672,000 in settlement of allegations it paid off interest free credit card debt from special offers before paying off normal debt, unfairly increasing customers' interest costs. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume they split the total equally.

The West Virginia Attorney General announced that Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase, Citibank and GE Money Bank would each pay the state $1.95 million to settle lawsuits alleging the companies' credit card protection programs violated West Virginia law.
Info Source: Attorney General Morrisey Announces Nearly $8 Million in Settlements in Payment Protection Lawsuit, Targeted News Service, September 24, 2013 (via Nexis).

The New York Attorney General announced a settlement with General Electric Capital Corporation in connection with a widespread telecommunications fraud involving NorVergence, Inc., a bankrupt New Jersey-based telephone equipment and service company.

GM agreed to pay up to $6.28 million in restitution to customers and $1 million to the state relating to a series of recalls, including recalls related to faulty ignition switches that could switch off while consumers were driving.

WebNet Communications, Inc. agreed to pay $4,134 in refunds and $10,000 to a Consumer Education Fund to settle allegations of switching customers' long-distance service without their permission or knowledge, a practice known as slamming.
price-gouging
Weinstein Mortuary and its officers agreed to pay $513,000 in settlement of allegations it deceived customers about burial procedures and overcharged them for services.

Wellington Homes, and 397 Properties, L.L.C. were found guilty of willful violations of the Consumer Fraud Act in connection with the advertising, sale and construction of residential homes in the Lea Eara Farms development and ordered to pay civil penalties.
failure to report a data breach
Info Source: Attorney General Reaches Settlement with Wellpoint in Consumer Data Breach; Insurer Will Pay $100,000 Over Private Data Accessible on Public Web Site, States News Service, July 5, 2011 (via Nexis).

Description: To resolve a case involving allegations of unfair health insurance reimbursement rates, WellPoint agreed to pay $10 million to a qualified nonprofit organization that would establish a new, independent database to help determine fair out-of-network reimbursement rates for consumers throughout the United States.

Wells Fargo agreed to pay $23.7 million to settle a lawsuit filed by eight states alleging deceptive advertising and problematic lending practices by Wachovia and World Savings (both acquired by Wells Fargo) when offering an option ARM loan known as a Pick-a-Pay loan.

The New York Attorney General announced settlements with five financial institutions in connection with a widespread telecommunications fraud involving NorVergence, Inc., a bankrupt New Jersey-based telephone equipment and service company.

Info Source: Attorney General Morrisey Announces $8M Settlement with Wells Fargo, States News Service, April 25, 2016 (via Nexis).

Description: Wells Fargo agreed to pay for loan modifications plus $741,465 to the state for foreclosure prevention in settlement of allegations to companies it acquired, Wachovia and Golden West Financial, violated state consumer protection laws by failing to fully explain the loan payments of adjustable-rate mortgages.

The California Attorney General and five district attorneys announced a $8,500,000 settlement with Wells Fargo Bank over privacy violations that included recording consumers' phone calls without timely telling consumers they were being recorded, as required by California law.

The New York Attorney General reached an agreement with ten banks to stop allowing their credit cards to be used for online gambling. The banks also agreed to pay a total of $335,000. The announcement did not specify how that amount would be divided among the banks. Here we assume it was split evenly among them.

CIT Group/Equipment Financing,  Lyon Financial Services and Wells Fargo Financial Leasing resolved multistate litigation by agreeing to forgo or refund a total of about $30 million in rental payments linked to telecommunications fraud involving NorVergence, Inc., a bankrupt New Jersey-based telephone equipment and service company. The announcement did not specify the size of the commitments being made by each of the companies. Here we assume the total was divided equally among them.

Wesco Credit Insurance Co. agreed to pay $100,000 in restitution and $25,000 to the state, in settlement of allegations it exceeded the statutory ceiling it could charge for premiums for its credit unemployment insurance products.

West Bottoms Hospitality, LLC and its owner were ordered to pay $43,463 in restitution and $87,346 in penalties and fees in judgment of charges it failed to provide a suitable wedding venue at the building it was renovating, and did not refund customer payments.

Company: West Chester Commons, L.P., College Arms, L.P., and Walters Pennsylvania 1, Inc.
Info Source: Settlement with West Chester Rental Companies Calls for Restitution for Certain Consumers, US State News, December 21, 2016 (via Nexis).

Description: deceptive marketing

Company: West Publishing Corporation and Thomson Reuters Tax Accounting Inc.
Info Source: Attorney General Bondi's Office Announces Significant Settlement with Law Book Publishers over Automatic Subscription Renewals, Targeted News Service, February 4, 2014 (via Nexis).

Company: West Virginia Vein and Skin Centers
Info Source: Attorney General McGraw Announces Settlement with Vein and Skin Centers; $93,000 Refunded to Consumers, US States News, November 13, 2008 (via Nexis).

Company: Westbury Nissan and Smithtown Nissan, Inc.
Westchester Foreign Autos, Inc., d/b/a Westchester Toyota
Western Sky Financial LLC, CashCall, Inc., WS Funding, LLC and Delbert Services Corp.
Description: Western Sky Financial LLC, CashCall, Inc., WS Funding, LLC, and Delbert Services Corp. agreed to jointly pay $1 million in restitution to settle allegations of unlawful lending.

Company: Western Sky Financial, CashCall Inc. and WS Funding
Description: Western Sky Financial, CashCall Inc., WS Funding and their owners jointly agreed to pay $750,000 to settle accusations of conspiring to offer illegal payday loans online to Arkansans while claiming to be affiliated with a Native American tribe.
Notes: Joint settlement is $500,000 restitution and $250,000 to Arkansas Consumer Education.

Company: Western Sky Financial, LLC and CashCall, Inc.
Description: Western Sky Financial, LLC and CashCall, Inc. agreed to set up a $2.2 million settlement fund in settlement of allegations they made unlicensed loans with illegally high interest rates in to Michigan customers. Later releases note that the total monetary value of the settlement including cancelled and modified loans was $24.7 million.

Company: Western Sky Financial, LLC et al.
Description: Western Sky Financial, LLC; Payday Financial, LLC, doing business as Lakota Cash and Big Sky Cash; Great Sky Finance, LLC; Green Billow, LLC, doing business as Four Seasons Cash; and Red Stone Financial, LLC agreed to pay $560,000 in settlement of allegations they violated Colorado credit protection laws by making unlicensed loans to Colorado consumers.

Company: Western Sky Financial, LLC, CashCall, Inc.
Description: Western Sky Financial, LLC, CashCall, Inc. and related entities agreed to pay $23.5 million in restitution, forgive $17 million in loans and pay $1.5 million in penalties, fees and costs, in settlement of allegations they violated Georgia's Payday Lending Act by being an unlicenced lender and charging above the legal interest rate.

Company: Western Sky Financial, LLC, WS Funding, LLC, CashCall, Inc., Delbert Services Corp.
Description: Western Sky Financial, LLC, WS Funding, LLC, CashCall, Inc., Delbert Services Corporation, and their owners agreed to pay $388,231 (half suspended) and $65,000 in fees in settlement of allegations they provided unlicensed loans with illegally high interest rates.

Western Union agreed to pay $5 million to resolve multistate litigation alleging that it failed to take adequate steps to prevent its wire transfer system from being used in schemes to defraud consumers.

Western Union Financial Services agreed to pay $8.529 million as part of the settlement of multistate litigation concerning the use of the company'?s wire transfer services by fraudulent telemarketers.
Westlake Services, LLC agreed to provide $5.7 million in debt relief in settlement of allegations it charged excessive interest rates on subprime auto loans.

Westwood College, Inc. agreed to pay $2 million in penalties, restitution, fees, and costs, plus another $2.5 million in restitution to students who used the school's financing, in settlement of allegations it misled students over graduate employment statistics and failed to comply with state consumer lending laws.

Weyerhaeuser agreed to pay $55,000 each to Oregon, Washington and Wisconsin and contribute $130,000 for research to resolve an investigation of alleged misrepresentations by the company about the performance of its engineered wood siding.

A jury found Whispering Oaks guilty of violating the Missouri Drinking Water Law by failing to maintain its water system and failing to provide an emergency system when the water supply failed at its residential care system for seriously disabled and mentally ill individuals, causing unsanitary conditions. It was ordered to pay $135,000 in penalties.

Notes: press release states "nearly $17,000"

Description: Do Not Call violation

Info Source: North Platte Gas Station to Change Advertising Practices, US States News, September 28, 2007 (via Nexis).

Company: William Gallagher Associates Insurance Brokers, Inc.
Description: Following a court-ordered audit, WGA was ordered to pay an additional $410,624 in restitution and penalties to eleven companies, as required under the terms of a December 2007 settlement over allegations WGA misled clients about its contingent commissions.

Company: William Gallagher Associates Insurance Brokers, Inc.
Description: WGA agreed to pay $3,017,003 in restitution and at least $925,000 in fees and costs in settlement of allegations it misled customers about the brokerage firm's contingent commission practices or its involvement in reinsurance, and did not disclose additional fees.
William Gallagher Associates, Inc. agreed to pay $1.7 million in settlement of allegations it concealed fees and commissions from its customers, resulting in them being overcharged.

William Raveis Real Estate Co. agreed to pay $200,000 to the state, $25,000 to the University of Connecticut, and an estimated $175,000 restitution, in settlement of allegations it charged a supplemental fee on real estate transactions that it misrepresented as required to comply with government regulations.

Company: Williams Asphalt Materials, LLC et al.

Description: Williamson and McKevie, LLC agreed to give up accounts worth $8.8 million and pay a $20,000 civil penalty in settlement of allegations it committed multiple violations of the federal Fair Debt Collection Practices Act and the Georgia Fair Business Practices Act when it repeatedly harassed and deceived consumers.

Info Source: Insurance Broker to Reimburse Policy Holders $2.6 Million, US States News, July 17, 2007 (via Nexis).

Description: Do Not Call violation

WindTech-Co. and its owner agreed to pay $488,000 in restitution in settlement of allegations it misled consumers in its marketing of wind turbines, failed to install turbines paid for by consumers, and provided unsafe wind turbine installations.
Do Not Call violation
deceptive practices

Wishbone Marketing LLC agreed to pay $25,000 in refunds and costs in settlement of alleged violations of Iowa's Buyers Club Law by enrolling consumers into monthly memberships without clear disclosure.

Company: Women & Infants Hospital of Rhode Island
Description: Women & Infants Hospital agreed to pay $150,000 to resolve allegations a data breach occured due to an inadequate inventory and tracking system that allowed back-up tapes containing personal and health information to be misplaced.
improper robo-calls
Agreed to pay $10,000 in settlement of alleged violations of the No-Call Act.

Info Source: Attorney General Abbott Reaches Settlement with Online Incentive Marketer, States News Service, May 14, 2008 (via Nexis).

Description: Agreed to pay $15,000 in settlement of alleged violations of the No-Call Act.

Company: World Gym of Lincoln Center, Inc.

Description: World Wide Readers Service was ordered to pay $5 million in civil penalties and more than $1 million in restitution for fraudulently billing consumers for magazine subscriptions.

Company: Worthington Commons LP and First Resource Management Company LLC
Description: Worthington Commons and First Resource agreed to pay a total of $25,000 to settle allegations they failed to respond to harassment of a tenant due to his sexual orientation at the apartments they owned and managed.

price-gouging
Info Source: Attorney General Abbott Resolves Price-Gouging Case Against Historic Hotel in San Antonio, States News Service, September 21, 2007 (via Nexis).

Description: Seven student loan companies agreed to reform their business practices and contribute a total of $1.4 million to a fund to assist students and their families. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was split evenly among them.
power outages
Info Source: Xcel to refund $1 million in power outage reporting case, Associaed Press, Sepember 24, 2003 (via Nexis).

Description: Xchange Leasing, LLC, a subsidiary of Uber, agreed to pay $210,000 in settlement of allegations it overcharged the Uber drivers using its car leasing services by improper handling of toll fees the cars were charged.

Xcite Satellite agreed to pay $40,000 to the state plus refunds to customers to settle allegations it violated the Iowa Door to Door Sales Act and Consumer Fraud Act by misrepresenting fees and services.
Xentel agreed to pay $30,000 in settlement of allegations it made misleading telemarketing calls.

Info Source: Attorney General Reaches Agreement with XM Brands Over Deceptive Marketing Practices, Targeted News Service, January 6, 2011 (via Nexis).

Company: Y2K Realty, Inc. dba Louisburg Properties

Description: Yapstone Holdings Inc. agreed to pay $155,000 to settle allegations it failed to protect personal information of customers when it accidentally removed password protection from its website and was aware of the vulnerability for a year before correcting it.

Yellow Pages Inc. agreed to pay $525,000 to settle multistate litigation alleging deceptive practices such as sending mailings in the form of checks that resembled a customer refund or rebate, but instead were a contract to buy business listings on the company's website.

YF Solution, LLC and its owner agreed to pay $10,000 in costs and penalties and repay consumers approximately $12,000 in settlement of allegations it violated the District's consumer protection laws, particularly by promising to significantly reduce consumers' debts, unlawfully charging fees in advance for debt relief services, and failing to deliver promised results.

YP.com and affiliate Telco Billing, Inc. agreed to pay restitution to businesses and nonprofit groups in 34 states under a $2 million-plus settlement that resolved allegations YP deceptively marketed enhanced advertising in its Internet yellow pages directory.

The California Attorney General announced an agreement forcing YTB International to stop the deceptive marketing of its largely unprofitable travel websites and prohibiting the company from charging consumers nearly $500 to recruit others.

Company: Zak Law Offices, P.C., and Loan Modification Group, Inc.
Description: A Revere attorney and his two businesses Zak Law Offices, P.C., and Loan Modification Group, Inc. were ordered to pay more than $625,000 in final judgment of allegations of using deceptive advertisements, illegal advance fees, and failing to deliver foreclosure relief.

Info Source: Attorney General Abbott Reaches Agreement with Zale Lipshy University Hospital to Provide Care to Poor, US States News, January 25, 2005 (via Nexis).
Zangara Dealerships Settle with Attorney General Madrid, US States News, April 11, 2006 (via Nexis).

Description: Zappos.com entered into a $106,000 settlement with nine states to resolve issues relating to a 2012 data breach that exposed the personal information of the website's consumers. The settlement required Zappos to undertake additional security measures to help prevent future data breaches.
deceptive practices aimed at Spanish-speaking customers

Agency: Transportation Department Aviation Consumer Protection Division

Company: Bayless Health Care dba Bayless Integrated Healthcare

Description: The California Attorney General announced a $213,167 settlement against Grass Advantage (also known as Amazing Grass), a nutrition company specializing in organic food supplements, resolving allegations that it sold and distributed products containing excessive levels of lead or cadmium in violation of California's Proposition 65 law.

Company: Catholic Medical Mission Board, Inc. et al.

Description: Colorado Attorney General Phil Weiser announced a settlement with Devumi, LLC, a company that created fake social media likes and followers to make its customers appear more popular and influential than they were.
The settlement resolved an investigation into allegations that Park 7 Residential, L.P. charged tenants for water despite lease agreements stating that the cost of water was included in rent.
Sanford Capital, LLC agreed to return over $1.1 million in rent payments to 155 tenants forced to live in uninhabitable conditions.
illegal short-term rentals

The Department of Justice reached a settlement agreement with MUY Brands LLC, a San Antonio, Texas-based owner and operator of approximately 78 Taco Bell restaurant franchises in six states, and a related management company, MUY Consulting Inc. The settlement resolved the Department's investigation into whether the companies violated the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) by discriminating against lawful permanent residents because of their citizenship status when verifying their authorization to work in the United States.

Description: AT&T Mobility, LLC agreed to pay $60 million to settle litigation with the Federal Trade Commission over allegations that the wireless provider misled millions of its smartphone customers by charging them for unlimited data plans while reducing their data speeds.

NatureCity agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations it deceived consumers with false and unsupported claims that two products, TrueAloe and AloeCran, were effective treatments for a range of conditions affecting seniors, including chronic pain, ulcerative colitis, diabetes, and acid reflux.

Multi-level marketer AdvoCare International, L.P. and its former chief executive officer agreed to pay $150 million and be banned from the multi-level marketing business to resolve Federal Trade Commission charges that the company operated an illegal pyramid scheme that deceived consumers into believing they could earn significant income as distributors of its health and wellness products.

Under a proposed consent order, Belize's Atlantic International Bank Limited will pay $23 million, representing approximately all of its U.S.-based assets, to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it assisted various related entities in deceiving U.S. consumers as part of a scheme to sell property in Sanctuary Belize.

The University of Rochester Medical Center agreed to pay $3 million to the HHS Office for Civil Rights and take substantial corrective action to settle potential violations of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) Privacy and Security Rules.
Agency: Health & Human Services Department Office for Civil Rights

Description: The HHS Office for Civil Rights imposed a civil money penalty of $2,154,000 against Jackson Health System for violations of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) Security and Breach Notification Rules between 2013 and 2016.
Agency: Health & Human Services Department Office for Civil Rights

TMC Bonds LLC, operator of an alternative trading system for fixed income securities, agreed to pay $2.1 million to settle charges arising from its failure to protect confidential subscriber information.
