Description: deceptive consumer repair sales practices
ALCO Iron & Metal agreed to pay $750,000 in settlement of allegations it underpaid customers by under-reporting the weight of recycled aluminum on its industrial truck scale during processing.

Company: GeoPharma, Inc. and Breakthrough Engineered Nutrition, Inc.

Description: Ford Motor Credit agreed to pay $1 million to the Alameda County District Attorney to resolve allegations of deceptive leasing practices.
Info Source: Alameda County, Ford Settle $1 Million Lawsuit, Valley Times, July 14, 2000 (via Nexis).

Description: JBI Management Inc., Linden Ventures LLC, 324 Central Realty LLC, Salmor Realty 2, LLC, Salmor Realty LLC, and their owners pleaded guilty to charges they attempted to force tenants out of rent-stabilized apartments by illegal means, so they could charge higher market-rate rents. The plea agreement included $248,000 in restitution and a $100,000 fund for tenants damaged by any of their unlawful acts.

Renovate America agreed to pay $4 million in settlement of allegations that under previous management it misrepresented the terms of a  clean energy program allowing the installation of energy efficiency projects to be financed by placing liens on the property, leading to customer problems when attempting to sell or refinance their homes. The case was jointly prosecuted by the Riverside, San Diego, Kern, Napa, Monterey, and Santa Cruz District Attorneys and the San Diego City Attorney.

The Sherwin-Williams Co., ConAgra and NL Industries agreed to pay a total of $305 million in settlement of allegations by the counties of Santa Clara, Alameda, Los Angeles, Monterey, San Mateo, Solano, and Ventura; the City and County of San Francisco; and the cities of Oakland and San Diego, that they manufactured paint products containing lead when its danger to public health was known.

The Sherwin-Williams Co., ConAgra and NL Industries agreed to pay a total of $305 million in settlement of allegations by the counties of Santa Clara, Alameda, Los Angeles, Monterey, San Mateo, Solano, and Ventura; the City and County of San Francisco; and the cities of Oakland and San Diego, that they manufactured paint products containing lead when its danger to public health was known.

The Sherwin-Williams Co., ConAgra and NL Industries agreed to pay a total of $305 million in settlement of allegations by the counties of Santa Clara, Alameda, Los Angeles, Monterey, San Mateo, Solano, and Ventura; the City and County of San Francisco; and the Cities of Oakland and San Diego, that they manufactured paint products containing lead when its danger to public health was known.

Pacific Gas and Electric Company agreed to pay $1 billion to resolve the wildfire claims brought by 18 local public entities (cities, counties, districts and public agencies) impacted by the 2015 Butte Fire, 2017 Northern California wildfires and 2018 Camp Fire.

Walmart, Inc. agreed to pay $495,000 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Fresno, Placer, Santa Cruz, Shasta, Tulare and Yolo counties that it sold health and beauty products in oversized containers.

Raley's agreed to pay $350,000 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Santa Clara, Shasta, Sacramento and Sonoma counties that it illegally sold over-the-counter medications and baby food and formula beyond the manufacturers' sell by or expiration dates.

GameStop agreed to pay $500,000 in settlement of allegations it violated California's second-hand dealer laws by failing to obtain proper identification, report transactions to law enforcement, and hold items for a minimum number of days before resale. The stipulated judgement was with the Shasta and Riverside District Attorneys.
Guthy-Renker LLC agreed to pay $8.5 million in penalties and restitution in settlement of allegations is did not clearly disclose automatic renewal charges  for products it sold on its website.

Ghirardelli and Russell Stover, both owned by Lindt & Sprungli, agreed to pay $750,000 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Fresno, Yolo, Scaramento, San Joaquin, Shasta and Santa Cruz counties that they packaged some chocolate products in oversized containers and that Ghirardelli sold one product containing less cocoa than stated.

Chevron agreed to pay $141,355 to the District Attorneys of Contra Costa, Riverside, Santa Cruz and Yolo counties to settle allegations that it failed to comply with a state law relating to cashing out of gift cards with low balances.
Info Source: Chevron to Pay $141,355 for Failing to Comply With California's Gift Card Redemption Laws, Targeted News Service, December 11, 2018 (via Nexis).

Description: Amazon.com agreed to pay $100,000 in settlement of allegations it unlawfully sold force-fed foie gras in California. The agreement was reached with the Los Angeles, Monterey, and Santa Clara County district attorneys.

Company: Allied Interstate LLC, and iQor Holdings Inc.
Description: Allied Interstate LLC and its parent IQor agreed to pay $8 million penalties and $1 million costs in settlement with 18 California district attorneys of allegations it violated state and federal laws regarding debt collection phone calls, with excessive calling, use of robodiallers, and calling cellphones without consent.

Spark Networks, owner of several dating websites, agreed to pay up to $985,000 in restitution and $500,000 in penalties in settlement of allegations it carried out automatic renewals of its services without express consent by customers. The suit was brought by the Santa Monica City Attorney's Office, and included the Los Angeles County Attorney's Office among others.

Tannerite Sports LLC agreed to pay $350,000 in settlement of allegations it sold exploding rifle targets that qualifed under California law as an explosive and destructive device. The settlement was with the Riverside and San Diego County District Attorneys.

Goop, Inc. agreed to pay $145,000 in settlement of allegations by ten California District Attorneys that the advertised medical claims for its Jade Egg, Rose Quartz Egg, and Inner Flower Essence Blend were not supported by reliable science.

Fitness Evolution agreed to pay $1.8 million in penalties, restitution and costs, and $0.5 million restitution to members who suffered harm from unauthorized charges, and to forgive $11 million in debt,  in settlement of charges by 8 California District Attorneys that it engaged in unfair business practices, false advertising, and deceptive membership terms.

Amazon.com agreed to pay $1,512,400 in settlement of allegations by 23 California District Attorneys that it misleadingly labeled plastic products as biodegradable or compostable. Amazon also agreed to make an additional payment of $50,000 to CalRecycle to fund testing of plastic products marketed to consumers as compostable or degradable.

Company: Ulta Salon, Cosmetics and Fragrance, Inc.
Description: Ulta agreed to pay $175,000 to the District Attorneys of Monterey and Riverside counties to resolve allegations about price scanner violations.

Dropbox agreed to pay $1.7 million penalties and costs, and set aside $450,000 for restitution, in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Alameda, San Diego, San Francisco and Sonoma counties that it violated California's Automatic Renewal Law by failing to display the terms in the manner required and failing to get the customers affirmative consent when selling subscription storage services.

Costco and JBR agreed to jointly pay $500,000 in settlement of allegations by 25 California District Attorneys that they sold plastic coffee pods with misleading marketing claims related to biodegradability and compostability. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the amount was divided equally between them.

Walgreens agreed to pay $2,250,000 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Santa Clara, Contra Costa, San Mateo and Santa Cruz counties that is sold expired baby food, infant formula, and over the counter drugs.

eHarmony agreed to pay $1.28 million in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Santa Clara, Santa Cruz, Napa, and Shasta counties,and the Santa Monica City Attorney's Office, that it misled customers by not clearly explaining the automatically charged subscription fee, did not provide customers their contract, and did not explain their right to cancel, as required by law.

Savvier, Inc. agreed to pay over $1 million in settlement of allegations by the California Food, Drug and Medical Device Task Force, which consists of 10 California District Attorneys, that its advertisements made fat reducing claims about its Tummy Tuck Belt that were not supported by reliable scientific evidence, as well as allegations it was not complying with laws requiring automatic renewal of subscription services to have clear and conspicuous disclosures.

CVS agreed to pay an additional $551,687 in modification of a previous settlement made in May 2015 for allegedly misleading pricing of products leading to overcharging customers. The new settlement was from alleged new violations discovered since, and was shared equally between the Los Angeles, Riverside and Santa Cruz county DA offices.

The District Attorneys of Contra Costa and Orange counties obtained nationwide restitution and a $1.3 million settlement from 24 Hour Fitness over allegations that the company misled longtime members on fixed annual renewal rates.

The California Department of Consumer Affairs announced that McDonald Hearing Aid Center agreed to pay a total of $600,000 in costs and civil penalties in settlement of allegations of fraud, deception, false advertising and unlawful business practices in a case brought by the District Attorneys of Contra Costa, Placer, Sacramento, Sonoma and Yolo counties.

The Los Angeles County District Attorney and the State Attorney General announced that People's Choice Charities agreed to pay $30,000 (and a $870,000 suspended penalty) to establish a charity fund in settlement of allegations it used misleading advertising stating that 100% of proceeds from donated cars would go to charity.
Notes: Settlement was with Los Angeles County and the State of California. The full payment to the fund is listed as the penalty.

Description: Bank of America agreed to pay a total of nearly $2 million to the Los Angeles, Alameda, Riverside, San Diego and Ventura county district attorneys in settlement of allegations it did not disclose its automatic recording of phone calls to customers in adequate time, as required by California law.
Mexilink, a hair gel distributor, agreed to pay $238,000 to the District Attorneys of Monterey and Riverside counties to resolve allegations of false advertising.
Lebanon Seaboard agreed to pay $175,000 to the District Attorneys of Placer, Riverside, San Joaquin and Yolo counties to resolve allegations that it used misleading packaging.

General Mills agreed to pay $375,000 to the District Attorneys of Fresno, Santa Cruz and Yolo counties to resolve allegations it put products in oversized packages, giving shoppers the impression they held more product than was present.
Info Source: Prosecutors settle with General Mills over food packaging, The Davis Enterprise, January 13, 2017 (via Nexis).

Description: Allstate agreed to pay $600,000 to the District Attorneys of Los Angeles, Riverside and San Diego counties in settlement of allegations it advertised an accident forgiveness program that was not available in California.
Wacoal America agreed to pay $350,000 to resolve allegations by a group of California district attorneys that it ran ads falsely claiming that its underwear promoted weight loss.

My Pillow agreed to pay $995,000 in penalties and $100,000 in charitable donations in settlement of allegations by the California Food, Drug and Medical Device Task Force, consisting of 10 California District Attorneys, that it falsely advertised the benefits of its products that were not supported by reliable evidence.

Liberty Mutual agreed to pay $925,000 to the District Attorneys of Los Angeles, Riverside and San Diego counties in settlement of allegations it advertised an accident forgiveness program that was not available in California, since it was illegal under state law.

In Shape Health Clubs agreed to a settlement valued at more than $26 million to end legal action against it for unfair business practices, false advertising and deceptive membership promotions that occurred from 2010 to 2015 as the company grew from 40 to 70 health clubs. The settlement was filed in Monterey County Superior Court by a joint District Attorney task force including Santa Cruz, Kern and Monterey counties.

Company: Equilon Enterprises, LLC dba Shell Oil
Description: Equilon Enterprises agreed to pay $762,500 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Santa Clara, Alameda, Monterey, Napa, Santa Cruz, Solano and Sonoma counties that it failed to adequately inform customers about limitations applying to its gift and reward cards and did not provide some customers with advertised discounts.

Active Network, LLC agreed to pay a $2.7 million civil penalty and $150,000 in costs and restitution in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Alameda, San Diego and Sonoma counties that it automatically renewed contracts for its member service for group activities without the clear disclosures required by California law.
Neurobrands LLC agreed to pay $500,000 to the Los Angeles County and Santa Monica City Attorneys in settlement of allegations it misled customers over the health benefits of its products.

Uber agreed to pay $25 million to Los Angeles and San Francisco counties ($15 million suspended) in settlement of allegations it misled customers about the background checks it carried out on its drivers.

Stamps.com agreed to pay $2.5 million in penalties in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Santa Clara and Santa Cruz that it advertised a no-risk trial without clearly disclosing that customers would be automatically enrolled onto a paid monthly service.

Walgreens agreed to pay $502,200 in settlement of allegations its pharmacists did not fully comply with the state Board of Pharmacy's rules requiring a personal consultation when customers received a new or changed prescription. The settlement was with the District Attorneys of of Alameda, Riverside and San Diego counties.

Company: Barwinners, and Legal Education Unlimited, Inc.
Description: Barwinners and its parent company agreed to pay $130,000 in a joint settlement with Los Angeles County and Santa Monica of alleged false advertising of the success rate of its online State Bar exam courses.

Kohl's Department Stores agreed to pay nearly $1 million in settlement of allegations it violated consumer protection laws by charging customers a higher price than advertised on store shelves and signage, and that it did not adequately disclose how discounts were applied to its loyalty program. The settlement was with the District Attorneys of Santa Cruz, Fresno, Shasta and Riverside counties and split equally between them after deducting the Riverside County Division of Weights & Measures costs of $4,718.

The Procter & Gamble Co. agreed  to pay $850,000 in settlement of allegations it violated California's slack fill law, using oversized packaging to make the product seem larger than it actually is. The settlement was with the District Attorneys of Yolo, Fresno, Shasta and Riverside counties and split equally between them.

CVS agreed to pay a $2.02 million civil penalty split equally among the District Attorneys of Los Angeles, Riverside and Ventura counties, plus costs and a consumer protection trust fund that brought the total to $2.4 million, in settlement of allegations it overcharged customers by charging more than the advertised price and failing to give cash back on gift cards under $10 value as required under state law.

Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. agreed to pay $820,000 in settlement of allegations by the City Attorney of San Diego and the District Attorneys of Tulare and Yolo counties that it misrepresented warranties on tires sold in its California stores.

C&F Foods, Inc., a food distributor and packager, entered into a stipulated judgment with the Alameda and Sonoma county District Attorneys to resolve labeling and slack-fill packaging violations in Sunny Select brand instant rice products.
Hershey agreed to pay $186,673 to the District Attorneys of Sacramento and Yolo counties to resolve allegations about the use of misleading packaging.

MyLife.com agreed to pay over $1 million in settlement of allegations it misled customers over its ability to identify who was searching for them on the internet while charging a year's membership fee upfront. $800,000 in civil penalties was divided equally between the Los Angeles District and Santa Monica City Attorneys, and $250,000 was paid in restitution.

Target Corp. agreed to pay over $3.3 million in penalties, plus over half a million dollars in costs and restitution, in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Fresno, Marin, Sonoma, Santa Cruz and Contra Costa counties and the San Diego City Attorney that it overcharged customers at the checkout for products it labeled or advertised at a lower price.
Notes: Full amount paid in settlement taken from the San Diego City Attorney press release.

Description: Johnson & Johnson agreed to pay $506,000 to the District Attorneys of Fresno, San Joaquin, Shasta and Yolo counties to resolve allegations that packaging for Neutrogena and other products was misleading.
Info Source: DA offices settle product packaging case, The Davis Enterprise, January 14, 2015 (via Nexis).

Description: Lyft agreed to pay a total of $500,000 ($250,000 suspended on condition of complying with settlement conditions within a year) to Los Angeles County and San Francisco County in settlement of allegations it made false and misleading statements to customers concerning its drivers' background checks, that it failed to get approval from state authorities that the measurements in its phone application were accurate, and that it failed to get authorization to operate at California airports.

Canine Care, Inc. agreed to pay $150,000 to the District Attorneys of Contra Costa, Fresno, Sacramento and Ventura counties to settle allegations it performed pet teeth cleaning services without licenses from the California Veterinary Medical Board.

Justfabulous, Inc. agreed to pay over $1.8 million in settlement of allegations by the Santa Clara and Santa Cruz District Attorneys that it misled customers by not clearly explaining that its advertised discounts required an automatically charged monthly subscription fee.

Sysco Corp. and its California operating companies agreed to pay $19.4 million in settlement of allegations by the California Food, Drug and Medical Device Task Force (consisting of 10 California District Attorneys) that it violated California's Health and Safety laws by transporting and storing potentially hazardous foods above a safe temperature.

Company: CSK Auto, Inc. dba O'Reilly Auto Parts, formerly Kragen Auto Parts.
Description: CSK Auto, Inc. agreed to pay more than $1.5 million in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys for San Bernardino, Santa Clara and Santa Cruz, counties along with the City Attorney of San Diego, that it charged customers more than the advertised or posted price for products at its check-out scanners, and that it failed to comply with the terms of its previous settlement in July 2008.

Rite Aid agreed to pay $498,250 in settlement of allegations its pharmacists did not fully comply with the state Board of Pharmacy's rules requiring a personal consultation when customers received a new or changed prescription. Settlement was with the District Attorneys of of Alameda, Riverside and San Diego counties.

Company: Whole Foods Market California, Inc., and Mrs. Gooch's Natural Food Markets, Inc.
Description: Whole Foods Market California, Inc., and Mrs. Gooch's Natural Food Markets, Inc. agreed to pay nearly $800,000 in settlement of allegations by the City Attorneys of Santa Monica, Los Angeles and San Diego that they overcharged customers at checkouts, failed to deduct the weight of containers in self-serve areas, and sold food items charged by the piece instead of by the pound.

Safeway agreed to pay $2.25 million in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Alameda, Marin, Fresno, Napa, Sacramento, Santa Cruz, Solano, Sonoma, and Ventura counties that it unlawfully charged consumers prices that were higher than its lowest advertised price, misrepresented the weight of Safeway-branded products, and made statements on in-store signage that conveyed the impression that certain produce was locally grown when in fact it had been sourced from outside California.

Overstock.com was ordered to pay $6.8 million in judgment of a lawsuit filed by the District Attorneys of Alameda, Marin, Monterey, Napa, Santa Clara, Santa Cruz, Shasta and Sonoma counties alleging that it used deceptive advertising to give customers the impression they were getting a bigger bargain, creating fictional comparison prices or using the highest comparison price.

Suarez Corporation Industries agreed to pay about $1.8 million in penalties and restitution in settlement of allegations by ten California District Attorneys that it made unsubstantiated claims about the health benefits of its products.

Company: Garfield Beach CVS, LLC, and Longs Drugs Stores, California, LLC
Description: Garfield Beach CVS, LLC, and Longs Drugs Stores, California, LLC, the owners of CVS-branded pharmacies, agreed to pay $658,500 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Alameda, Riverside and San Diego counties and the California Board of Pharmacy, that their stores failed to conduct the personal pharmacist consultations Board regulations require for every patient receiving new or changed prescription drugs.

Blue Rhino (Ferrellgas) and AmeriGas agreed to pay $1 million and $0.8 million respectively in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Alameda, Fresno, Monterey, San Joaquin, Santa Clara, Sonoma, and Ventura counties that they reduced the amount of propane sold in their barbeque propane cylinders while keeping the tanks locked in cages before purchase, stopping customers from noticing that the content had been reduced.

Company: Ferrellgas Partners L.P. and Ferrellgas L.P.
Description: Blue Rhino (Ferrellgas) and AmeriGas agreed to pay $1 million and $0.8 million respectively in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Alameda, Fresno, Monterey, San Joaquin, Santa Clara, Sonoma, and Ventura counties that they reduced the amount of propane sold in their barbeque propane cylinders while keeping the tanks locked in cages before purchase, stopping customers from noticing that the content had been reduced.

Toys R Us agreed to pay $75,000 to both Los Angeles and San Diego counties, and $28,730 costs split between four Weight and Measures departments, in settlement of allegations it overcharged customers with significant checkstand pricing errors.
Sims Group USA agreed to pay $4.1 million in settlement of allegations by the San Francisco and Contra Costa County District Attorneys that it bought metal without following regulations.

Kohl's agreed to pay $409,500 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys in Santa Clara, Santa Cruz, Fresno and Sacramento counties that it inaccurately priced items at its stores, and that sale prices and discounts were not always registered at check-out scanners.

Fidelity National Financial, Inc. entered into a settlement in the amount of $873,588 with California district attorneys in an unfair competition lawsuit regarding Fidelity's Transaction Point real estate software system.

Company: Sensa Products, LLC and Intelligent Beauty Inc.
Description: Sensa Products, LLC and Intelligent Beauty Inc. agreed to pay a total of $905,000 in settlement of allegations by a group of California District Attorneys that it made unproven claims for a product's weight loss effectiveness.

Horizon Group agreed to pay $225,000 in settlement of allegations by the San Diego City and County Attorneys that it deceptively packaged its Disney Princess jewelry kit by only filling half of the compartments and covering the empty compartments with packaging.

Rite Aid agreed to pay $800,000 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys in Santa Clara, Riverside and Ventura counties plus the San Diego City Attorney that it deceptively advertised its reward cards as reducing prices, and also that it failed to redeem gift cards with a cash value of less than $10.

Staples agreed to pay $968,157 to the District Attorneys of Contra Costa, Marin and Napa counties to resolve allegations that it violated a state law prohibiting a company from charging more than the lowest posted or advertised price.
Info Source: Staples Settles Consumer Protection Case for Price Scanner Overcharges, Targeted News Service, August 15, 2012 (via Nexis).

Description: Bumble Bee Foods, Tri-Union Seafoods (which markets Chicken of the Sea) and StarKist agreed to pay $3.3 million to District Attorneys in Marin, Riverside and San Diego counties to resolve allegations that they failed to meet federal standards relating to the amount of fish in their cans of tuna. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among the three.

Bumble Bee Foods, Tri-Union Seafoods (which markets Chicken of the Sea) and StarKist agreed to pay $3.3 million to District Attorneys in Marin, Riverside and San Diego counties to resolve allegations that they failed to meet federal standards relating to the amount of fish in their cans of tuna. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among the three.

Bumble Bee Foods, Tri-Union Seafoods (which markets Chicken of the Sea) and StarKist agreed to pay $3.3 million to District Attorneys in Marin, Riverside and San Diego counties to resolve allegations that they failed to meet federal standards relating to the amount of fish in their cans of tuna. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among the three.

Company Nurse LLC agreed to pay $200,00 to six California District Attorneys to resolve allegations that it failed to register with a state telephone medical advice bureau and failed to ensure that those providing phone advice were licensed registered nurses.
Info Source: Settlement reached between RN advice nurse service and Califoriia DAs, Sacramento Bee, March 19, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: Daiso California agreed to pay $350,000 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Santa Clara and Alameda counties that it sold toys and other children's products made of materials containing lead, lead compounds or certain phthalate compounds without clear warnings, in violation of California's Proposition 65.

Iovate Health Sciences, Inc. and its American affiliate agreed to pay $1.5 million in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys in Santa Clara, Santa Cruz, Napa, Alameda, Marin, Monterey, Orange, Shasta, Solano and Sonoma counties that it made false and misleading representations about some of its products and marketed a product with over 0.5 micrograms of lead without the warning label required by California's Proposition 65.

Clorox Co. agreed to pay $199,654 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Alameda, Marin, Monterey, Napa and Sonoma counties that it sold speciality bleach products in bottles that were under-filled, in violation of California laws.

Money Mart agreed to pay $7.5 million in restitution, forgive $8 million in loans, and pay the City and County of San Francisco $875,000 in settlement of allegations it made short term loads at exorbitant and illegal interest rates, in an arrangement with an out-of-state bank in an effort to circumvent California limits on interest rates.

National Arbitration Forum agreed to pay $1 million to the CIty and County of San Francisco in settlement of allegations it claimed to be a neutral arbitrator for credit card companies and consumers, while secretly partly owned by a hedge fund that also owned one of its debt collector clients.

Campbell Soup Co. agreed to pay $173,693 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Alameda and San Diego counties that it engaged in misleading advertising practices about the percentage reduction of sodium in its reduced sodium soup.
CVS agreed to pay $2 million in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Los Angeles, Riverside and Ventura counties that it overcharged customers for sale items at the checkout.

A publishing arm of credit card issuer American Express Corp. agreed to pay $600,000 in penalties to settle a false advertising case brought by District Attorneys in Marin, Napa, Sonoma, Solano and Santa Cruz counties.
Info Source: American Express to settle with Bay Area counties over alleged false advertising, San Jose Mercury News, May 20, 2011 (via Nexis).

Description: Irwin Naturals, Inc. agreed to pay $2.65 million in settlement of allegations by  the District Attorneys in Orange, Santa Clara, Santa Cruz, Alameda, Marin, Napa, Solano, Sonoma, Monterey, and Shasta counties that it made false and misleading representations about some of its products and marketed a product with over 0.5 micrograms of lead without the warning label required by California's Proposition 65.

LG Electronics, Panasonic, Samsung, Sharp and Sony agreed to pay a total of $1.25 million and contribute $1.125 million of audio-visual equipment to Californian schools and institutions in settlement of allegations by District Attorneys in seven counties that they violated state law by stating TV screen sizes rounded to the nearest inch. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the amounts were divided equally among the five.

LG Electronics, Panasonic, Samsung, Sharp and Sony agreed to pay a total of $1.25 million and contribute $1.125 million of audio-visual equipment to Californian schools and institutions in settlement of allegations by District Attorneys in seven counties that they violated state law by stating TV screen sizes rounded to the nearest inch. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the amounts were divided equally among the five.

LG Electronics, Panasonic, Samsung, Sharp and Sony agreed to pay a total of $1.25 million and contribute $1.125 million of audio-visual equipment to Californian schools and institutions in settlement of allegations by District Attorneys in seven counties that they violated state law by stating TV screen sizes rounded to the nearest inch. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the amounts were divided equally among the five.

Parent Company: Foxconn Technology Group (Hon Hai Precision Industry Company)
Description: LG Electronics, Panasonic, Samsung, Sharp and Sony agreed to pay a total of $1.25 million and contribute $1.125 million of audio-visual equipment to Californian schools and institutions in settlement of allegations by District Attorney Offices in seven counties that they violated state law by stating TV screen sizes rounded to the nearest inch. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the amounts were divided equally among the five.

LG Electronics, Panasonic, Samsung, Sharp and Sony agreed to pay a total of $1.25 million and contribute $1.125 million of audio-visual equipment to Californian schools and institutions in settlement of allegations by District Attorneys in seven counties that they violated state law by stating TV screen sizes rounded to the nearest inch. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the amounts were divided equally among the five.

Matrixx Initiatives, maker of Zicam medicines, agreed to pay $428,800 in settlement of allegations by five California District Attorneys that it violated state laws by packaging products with extra space that misled consumers as to the actual size.

Sears, Roebuck and Co. and Kmart agreed to pay a total of $1.1 million in settlement of allegations by six California District Attorneys that they charged more for California Redemption Value beverage containers than allowed by law, and that Kmart charged the fee for containers it did not apply to.

PETCO agreed to pay $1.75 million in settlement of allegations by five California District Attorneys and the City Attorney of San Diego that it overcharged customers and failed to properly care for animals.
Starbucks agreed to pay $225,000 to the District Attorneys of Monterey, Shasta and Sonoma counties to resolve allegations it failed to refund gift card balances to customers.
Info Source: NorCal DAs reach settlement with Starbucks, Associated Press, August 18, 2009 (via Nexis).

Description: Blockbuster agreed to pay $300,000 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Los Angeles and San Diego counties that it charged customers more than the advertised or posted price at checkouts.

Reckitt Benckiser, producer of Mucinex, agreed to pay more than $300,000 to the District Attorneys of Los Angeles, Sacramento and Shasta counties to resolve allegations it engaged in misleading packaging practices.
Info Source: Mucinex maker coughs up $300K to settle case, Sacramento Business Journal, December 19, 2008 (via Nexis).

Company: CSK Auto, Inc. dba Kragen Auto Parts.
Description: CSK Auto, Inc. agreed to pay $665,610 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys for Santa Cruz, San Bernardino and Santa Cruz counties that it charged customers more than the advertised or posted price for products at its check-out scanners.

Target Corp. agreed to pay over $1.7 million in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Fresno, Marin, Sonoma, Santa Cruz and Contra Costa counties that it overcharged customers at the checkout for products it labeled or advertised at a lower price.

Kelly-Moore Paint Company, Inc. agreed to pay $568,138 in settlement of allegations by District Attorneys in San Mateo, Santa Clara, Santa Cruz and Alameda counties that it charged customers more than the advertised or posted price for products at its check-out scanners.

Walgreens agreed to pay $767,000 to the District Attorneys of San Mateo and Santa Clara counties to resolve allegations that of discrepancies between posted prices and what was charged at the register.
Info Source: Settlement reached in price dispute, Inside Bay Area, December 27, 2007 (via Nexis).

Description: Archstone-Smith agreed to pay a total of $678,942 in penalties, costs and registration fees, plus an undecided amount of restitution, in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Los Angeles, Santa Clara and San Diego counties that it failed to follow follow state law for accurately billing tenants for water usage.

Office Depot agreed to pay over $2.5 million in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Marin, Sonoma, Santa Clara, Ventura, Solano, Napa, Shasta, Sacramento, and Los Angeles counties, and the City Attorney of the City of Los Angeles that it overcharged customers through inaccurate pricing at its checkout scanners.

Longs Drug Stores agreed to pay $1 million in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Santa Clara, Marin, Santa Barbara and Sonoma Counties and the City Attorney for the City of San Diego that it failed to charge the lowest advertised or posted price of items in its stores when they were scanned at the check-out register.

Smart & Final agreed to pay a $437,500 civil penalty and $3.6 million in restitution in settlement of allegations by the Santa Clara, Santa Barbara and Solano District Attorneys and the City Attorney for the City of San Diego that it failed to charge the advertised or posted prices for items at its checkout registers.
Diet pill producer Nutraquest agreed to pay $1 million to ten local California prosecutors and the state attorney general to resolve false advertising allegations.
Info Source: District attorneys reach $1 million deal with diet pill maker, Associated Press, June 16, 2006 (via Nexis).

Description: Albertsons agreed to pay $2 million to the District Attorneys of Monterey, Napa and Solano counties as well as the City Attorney of San Diego to resolve allegations that it failed to subtract the weight of certain packaging when charging customers for deli products and bulk food items including coffee and candy.
Info Source: Albertson's Settles Case Involving Alleged Unfair Business Practices, US States News, May 31, 2006 (via Nexis).

Company: Northern California, LLC, and Quikrete of Southern California, LLC
Description: Northern California, LLC, and Quikrete of Southern California, LLC agreed to pay $275,000 in settlement of allegations by Ventura, San Bernardino, Santa Clara, Los Angeles, Orange, Monterey, Fresno, Riverside, and Tulare County District Attorney Offices that it produced and sold masonry products that were short-weighted.

West Marine Products, Inc. agreed to pay $389,748 in settlement of allegations by the Santa Clara and Santa Cruz County District Attorneys that it did not correctly charge the lowest price advertised or posted for products in its stores at the checkout registers.

Walgreens agreed to pay $125,000 to resolve allegations by the District Attorneys of Napa, Solano and San Diego counties that it helped promote false advertising claims for a device called the AbEnergizer.
Info Source: Wal-Mart, Walgreens lose AbEnergizer suit, UPI, March 30, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: Wal-Mart agreed to pay $525,000 to resolve allegations by the District Attorneys of Napa, Solano and San Diego counties that it helped promote false advertising claims for a device called the AbEnergizer.
Info Source: Wal-Mart, Walgreens lose AbEnergizer suit, UPI, March 30, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: Body Wise International agreed to pay $1.58 million to the Orange County District Attorney and the California Attorney General to resolve allegations of making false claims about the health benefits of its AG-Immune supplement. The Federal Trade Commission was also involved in the case and separately collected $2 million; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-body-wise-international-inc
Info Source: Body Wise to pay $3.58 million in consumer-fraud settlement, Orange County Register, January 19, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: Basalite Concrete Products LLC agreed to pay $196,672 in settlement of allegations by Santa Clara, Monterey and Merced counties that it sold masonry products that were short-weight compared to the net weight represented on the package.
PETCO agreed to pay $854,254 in settlement of allegations by four California District Attorneys that it overcharged customers and failed to properly care for animals.
Macy's agreed to pay $1.2 million in settlement of allegations by five California District Attorneys that it failed to charge customers accurate prices at checkout scanners.

K-B Toys agreed to pay $500,000 in fines, penalties and costs and to distribute $687,000 in toys to needy children to settle a false-advertising case brought by district attorneys in Sacramento and Napa counties.
Info Source: K-B Toys fined for false ads, Sacramento Bee, August 20, 2003 (via Nexis).

Company: Cos-Medical, Inc. and Cos-Medical International, Inc.
Description: The District Attorneys of Santa Clara and Orange Counties settled a civil lawsuit against Cos-Medical, Inc. and Cos-Medical International, Inc.  alleging that the defendants violated California Weight Loss Contract law and made misleading claims about the effectiveness of programs, products, and profitability of licensing/distributor agreements.

Sorrento Lactalis, Inc. agreed to pay a total of $303,829 in settlement of allegations by San Bernardino, Santa Clara, Orange, Monterey and Fresno counties that it misrepresented the net weight on the packages and labels of cheese products it sold.

In a case brought by the San Francisco City Attorney and District Attorney, Old Republic was ordered to pay over $5 million in judgment of allegations it illegally kept interest from escrow bank accounts.

Milfico Foods agreed to pay $60,000 in a settlement of allegations by Santa Clara and Santa Cruz Counties that it included the weight of ice glaze in the labelled weight of the frozen seafood it sold.

Company: Julielle Enterprises, Inc. dba Table For Six

Description: Albertson's was fined $30,000 by the district attorneys of Alameda and San Francisco counties for mislabeling wines.
Safeway was fined $30,000 by the district attorneys of Alameda and San Francisco counties for mislabeling wines.

Company: Wade Cook Financial Corp. and Wade Cook Seminars
Description: The Fresno County District Attorney's Office and the state attorney general filed a settlement agreement with Wade Cook Financial Corp. and Wade Cook Seminars Wednesday that was expected to provide as many as 22,000 California consumers with more than $10 million in refunds.
Info Source: Settlement in seminar case could yield $10m, Fresno Bee, December 21, 2000 (via Nexis).

Company: Ford Motor Credit Corporation et al.
Description: Ford Motor Credit Co. agreed to pay $111,921 and 204 Ford and Lincoln-Mercury dealers in California agreed to pay $822,500 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Los Angles, Alameda and Sacramento counties that they deceptively placed improper charges on lease termination agreements.

Heinz Co. agreed to pay $180,000 in civil penalties and overfill its ketchup containers through California at an estimated cost of $651,000 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Los Angeles and Shasta counties that it underfilled certain ketchup products.

Rite Aid Corp. agreed to pay $2.8 million in civil penalties to settle a lawsuit filed by a dozen California District Attorneys and the San Diego City Attorney alleging that it engaged in misleading advertising and unfair competition.
Info Source: Rite Aid to Pay $2.8 Million; Alameda County, Other Agencies Filed Suit, San Jose Mercury News, April 14, 2000 (via Nexis).

Company: Circosta Iron and Metal Company, Inc.
Description: Circosta Iron and Metal agreed to pay $500,000 in settlement of allegations it failed to follow state Metal Theft Prevention laws requiring it to take steps to determine it is not purchasing stolen material by recording the identification of individuals selling certain materials and delaying payment for three days.
Agency: City and County of San Francisco (CA) District Attorney

Company: Pinnacle Security LLC and Pinnacle Security CA, LP
Info Source: Door-to-door alarm system sales firms to pay $525,000 settlement, Contra Costa Times, February 2, 2013 (via Nexis).

Description: Sears, Roebuck and Co. agreed to pay $450,000 in settlement of allegations of sales tax errors and overselling of oil and repairs in its Sears Automotive Repair Dealerships.

Company: Harris County Bone & Joint Clinic Association
Info Source: Clinic to pay $ 25,000 for violations, Houston Chronicle, April 6, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: The Los Angeles City Attorney entered into a four-year statewide stipulated judgment with NEwhere Inc. and VapeCo Distribution LLC over allegations that the companies illegally marketed vape products to minors and sold vaping products over the internet without following state-mandated age verification requirements. The companies each paid a penalty of $35,000.

The Los Angeles City Attorney entered into a four-year statewide stipulated judgment with NEwhere Inc. and VapeCo Distribution LLC over allegations that the companies illegally marketed vape products to minors and sold vaping products over the internet without following state-mandated age verification requirements. The companies each paid a penalty of $35,000.

Rainbow Light Nutritional Systems, LLC, a subsidiary of the Clorox Co., agreed to pay $250,000 in civil penalties and costs plus $1.5 million in restitution in settlement of allegations it advertised vitamins as free of heavy metals, but which were found to have detectable amounts of lead.
Venice Beach Suites, LLC agreed to pay $200,000 in penalties as part of a settlement of allegations it illegally ran units in a rent-stabilized apartment building as a hotel.
Silver Lake Medical Center agreed to pay $550,000 towards a Homeless Patient Assistance Program in settlement of allegations it improperly discharged homeless patients.

California Restoration agreed to pay $488,000 in penalties and restitution in settlement of allegations it misled and defrauded customers over contracts for water damage restoration, along with other unlawful business practices.

Gardens Regional Hospital agreed to pay $450,000 in settlement of allegations it discharged a homeless schizophrenic multiple times without a discharge plan, and had once left the patient in Skid Row in hospital clothes without money, identification or medication.
US Bank agreed to pay $13.5 million in settlement of allegations it allowed foreclosed properties in Los Angeles to fall into disrepair.

Wells Fargo agreed to pay $50 million in civil penalties in settlement of allegations it opened accounts without the customers' consent and without informing them, leading to unwanted fees and financial consequences. Federal agencies separately settled these allegations at the same time.

Good Samaritan Hospital agreed to pay $450,000 in settlement of allegations it discharged homeless patients without a proper discharge plan and without their informed consent to be transported to a location other than a residence.
patient dumping
Info Source: Local hospital owner settles dumping suit; City attorney sued over 2007 case of homeless woman who was left in West L.A., Los Angeles Times, March 19, 2011 (via Nexis).

Description: Ralphs Grocery Co. was ordered to pay more than $67,600 and was placed on three years' probation after pleading no contest to overcharging customers for prepackaged and weighed products at stores in Los Angeles.
Info Source: Ralphs faces fine and probation, Los Angeles Times, March 3, 2011 (via Nexis).

Description: patient dumping
Info Source: Skid row dumping suit settled; Hospital charged with leaving a paraplegic patient on the street will pay $1 million and have a federal monitor, Los Angeles Times, May 31, 2008 (via Nexis).

Description: patient dumping
Info Source: Kaiser accepts settlement to end dumping of homeless patients; The pact could resolve cases filed against the HMO after a woman was left to wander skid row, Los Angeles Times, May 16, 2007 (via Nexis).
Cellular Settlement, City News Service, August 23, 2001 (via Nexis).
Cellular Settlement, City News Service, August 23, 2001 (via Nexis).

Description: j2 Global, Inc. agreed to pay $1.2 million in penalties and restitution in settlement of allegations it automatically renewed subscriptions for their fax service without the full knowledge and consent of their customers, in violation of state law.
Guthy-Renker LLC agreed to pay $8.5 million in penalties and restitution in settlement of allegations is did not clearly disclose automatic renewal charges  for products it sold on its website.

Power Toyota Cerritos, a subsidiary of Mr. Wheels Inc., agreed to pay $172,000 in settlement of allegations some staff made false and misleading statements to persuade customers to lease cars instead of buying them.

McKenna Motor Co. Inc., parent of McKenna BMW, agreed to pay $654,258 in settlement of allegations it misrepresented the charges for aftermarket products, resulting in undisclosed charges for customers.

Honda of Santa Monica, a car dealership owned by Kramer Motors Inc., agreed to pay over $1.37 million in settlement of allegations it made false or misleading statements particularly on contracts regarding the price of aftermarket products included with vehicles sold or leased.
The maker of AriZona Tea agreed to stop selling some of its beverages under labels that implied they had medicinal or prescription-like health benefits.
Info Source: AriZona Tea maker agrees to stop using misleading labels, Associated Press, January 4, 2003 (via Nexis).

Company: World Kitchen Inc. dba Corning Revere Factory Stores

Description: Scher Tire agreed to pay $121,500 in settlement of allegations it sold unnecessary repairs or replacements, failed to complete work, failed to give written estimates and kept inaccurate invoices and business records.

Company: El Monte Motors, Inc. dba Gunderson Chevrolet
Description: El Monte Motors, doing business as Gunderson Chevrolet, agreed to pay approximately $2.5 million in penalties, costs and restitution in settlement of allegations it gave customers false and misleading information about the costs of vehicles and that some managers changed the terms on car purchases and leases without the knowledge or consent of customers.

MetLife agreed to pay $10 million in a Deferred Prosecution Agreement settling allegations it violated New York Insurance Law and the New York Penal Law for by operating two subsidiaries that did not pay for insurance licensing.
XANGO agreed to pay $200,000 in restitution to settle allegations it was used to conceal money defrauded by the owner of North American Coin and Currency.
A Westbury fish wholesaler that serviced popular Long Island restaurants was fined $100,000 for trafficking shellfish without necessary permits.

In exchange for agreeing not to prosecute Wal-Mart in connection with a fatal trampling incident during a Thanksgiving weekend sale, the Nassau County Distric Attorney got Wal-Mart to implement an improved statewide crowd-management plan at each of its 92 New York stores, along with a $400,000 victims' compensation and remuneration fund, a donation of  $1.5 million to the community and the creation of 50 jobs annually for Nassau teens.

Green Group LP and co-owners of a residential in the Chinatown neighborhood of Oakland agreed to pay $1 million to resolve allegations that they forced out tenants in order to remodel and re-lease apartments at higher rents.
blight violations
Sears agreed to pay $235,000 in civil penalties and was barred from selling misbranded or falsely advertised supplements under a settlement reached with the Orange County District Attorney's Office.
Orange County obtained $500,000 as part of a settlement with an Arkansas-based oil company accused of mislabeling motor and gear oil in several of its products.
An online-advertising company agreed to pay $142,500 for defrauding consumers in a solicitation-check scheme.

Nutritional supplement company Vitalife Inc. agreed to pay $1.02 million in civil penalties and costs and provide refunds to customers after settling a consumer protection lawsuit with the Orange County District Attorney that alleged false advertising, refusing refunds on unwanted products and failing to use required warning labels.
Info Source: Health company in Irvine to pay $1.02 million; Vitalife, which makes dietary supplements, also must offer refunds to its customers, Orange County Register, April 5, 2008 (via Nexis).
DA settles advertising case, Orange County Register, August 10, 2006.

Description: Microsoft Corp. agreed to pay $100,000 to settle a consumer-protection lawsuit with the Orange County district attorney that alleged customers faced difficulties when trying to cancel their Internet accounts.
Info Source: Microsoft to settle suit over Internet accounts, Orange County Register, March 6, 2002 (via Nexis).

Description: Motel 6 agreed to contribute $750,000 to the Sacramento County District Attorney's Office of Public Safety and Community Improvement Trust Fund in a Memorandum of Understanding settling allegations its properties were failing to meet acceptable industry standards and practices, causing nuisances in the county.

IntelliGender and its principals was ordered to pay $250,000 to resolve allegations it violated false advertising and hazardous substance laws, plus theft by false pretenses by marketing and selling a Gender Prediction Test that was not accurate and contained a corrosive chemical.
Luberski, Inc. agreed to pay $53,517 in penalties and costs, and donate $50,000 in eggs to city food banks, in settlement of allegations the labelling on its egg packages was misleading.
Ultimate Fitness Nutrition pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges related to selling dietary supplements and was ordered to pay a $5,500 fine.

Fresh & Easy Neighborhood Market, Inc. agreed to pay $833,136 in settlement of allegations by the San Diego and Riverside District Attorneys plus the San Diego City Attorney that it overcharged customers at checkout for items that they had labelled or advertised as cheaper on the shelf.

Notes: Joint investigation with the Drug Enforcement Administration.

Description: A Chicago company that sent letters to San Diego property owners mimicking county assessor notices agreed to pay a $115,000 fine and take other steps in a settlement with the San Diego County District Attorney's Office.
Info Source: Settlement reached in tax-form offer suit, San Diego Union-Tribune, July 9, 2004 (via Nexis).
Dodge World owner penalized over ads, San Diego Union-Tribune, August 31, 2001 (via Nexis).

Company: Compana Exportadora de Aguas Minerales, S.A. de C.V.
Description: A Mexican bottling company was ordered to pay more than $122,000 in fines and costs for failing to completely fill bottles of mineral water imported and sold in San Diego.
Info Source: Mexican bottler fined over fill-level discrepancies, San Diego Union-Tribune, August 31, 2001 (via Nexis).

Description: discrimination against low-income tenants

Company: Hertz Corp. and American Traffic Solutions
Description: Hertz Corp. and American Traffic Solutions agreed to pay $3.65 million in settlement of allegations they charged charged hidden fees to rental car customers who crossed the Golden Gate Bridge.
MeetMe agreed to pay $200,000 in settlement of allegations its social networking service did not meet legal requirements of privacy and safety protections for minors.

Educational Management Corp. agreed to pay a total of $4.4 million in penalties and scholarship funds in settlement of allegations it deceptively marketed college courses by underestimating costs and inflating job placement figures.
Bayview Property Managers agreed to pay $800,000 in settlement of allegations its rental properties were not compliant with city regulations.
FIA Card Services agreed to pay $5 million in settlement of allegations it was biased in credit card arbitration.

CitiApartments agreed to pay a settlement in the range of $1 million to $10 million to end a lawsuit alleging it harassed its tenants to vacate apartments that were then renovated to house new tenants at much higher rates. The civil penalties were dependent on the defendant's financial condition over the following years.

PG&E agreed to pay $6.5 million to the City and County of San Francisco in settlement of allegations its neglect was responsible for a power outage in December 2003 caused by a fire at its Mission Street substation.

AIMCO agreed to pay $1 million to fund a new clubhouse for the Boys and Girls Club of San Francisco in settlement of allegations concerning federally subsidized apartment complexes it owned and operated.

Grosvenor Properties and the general partnership Dr. R agreed to pay a total of $500,000 as part of a settlement of allegations they converted apartments into tourist rentals in violation of city ordinances and planning codes.

Harsch Investment agreed to pay $1.46 million in settlement of allegations it violated the Residential Hotel Conversion Ordinance by converting residential rooms at its Allison Hotel into rooms for tourists.

Adore Me agreed to pay $600,000 in settlement of allegations it misled customers by failing to clearly disclose automatic charges for VIP memberships, failing to get the proper consent or give proper notice for automatic renewal, falsely advertising the ability to use store credit, and having unfair cancellation practices.

Company: AS Restaurant Consulting Group LLC, dba Odeum Restaurant
Description: Odeum Restaurant and its owner agreed to pay $120,000 in civil penalties and restitution in settlement of allegations it was selling customers tilapia when they ordered petrale sole.

Company: Todd Christopher International dba Vogue International
San Jose Investments and Beaumont Investments
Description: San Jose Investments and Beaumont Investments were ordered to pay over $960,000 in restitution and $735,000 in civil penalties in judgment of charges they violated San Jose mobile home rent control ordinance by having local dealers sign long term leases they claimed were exempt from rent control ordinances which the dealers rented out at higher prices.

Description: Takata Corp. agreed to pay $7 million to Hawaii, the U.S. Virgin Islands, and the State of New Mexico in settlement of allegations it knowingly sold airbags containing a chemical propellant that could degrade in a dangerous fashion. This settlement was separate from a larger multistate lawsuit.
Agency: Hawaii Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs
Hawaii Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs

Description: Francha Services and its owner were ordered to pay over $1 million in restitution and civil penalties to resolve allegations of accepting payment for foreclosure relief services and then providing poor or no service to customers.
Agency: Hawaii Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs

Description: Meridian Sports Clubs California agreed to pay over $2 million in civil penalties and costs, in settlement of allegations its Gold Club Memberships violated state consumer protection statutes. Since Meridian was in bankruptcy is was expected that the actual recovery would be much less.
Agency: Hawaii Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs
Hawaii Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs
Hawaii Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs

Company: Pacific Educational Services Co. dba Hawaii College of Pharmacy
Description: Pacific Educational Services Co., along with its founder, was ordered to pay approximately $6.5 million in restitution and $7.5 million in civil penalties to resolve allegations it misrepresented its accreditation, used deceptive trade practices, and retaliated against students who filed complaints.
Agency: Hawaii Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs

Company: Aloha Adventure Camps, and Hawaiian Cultural Preservation Association
Description: Aloha Adventure Camps and the Hawaiian Cultural Preservation Association, along with their owner, were judged to be in violation of state consumer protection laws when a Maui summer camp closed without warning or refunds and were ordered to pay refunds plus $250,000 civil penalties, although the owner's whereabouts were unknown.
Agency: Hawaii Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs

Description: Hy Cite Corporation,seller of cookware and water filters under the name of Royal Prestige, agreed to pay $1.35 million for victim restitution and penalties and drastically reform how it does business to resolve allegations that it lied to consumers to gete them to pay several thousand dollars each for cookware and water filters.
Agency: Los Angeles (CA) County Department of Consumer and Business Affairs
Info Source: National Corporation Pays $1.35 Million and Drastically Reforms Its Business to Resolve State Charges That it Used Fraudulent and Discriminatory Practices, Targeted News Service, January 13, 2010 (via Nexis).

Company: ATA Consulting LLC dba Best Medical Transcription
Description: ATA Consulting and its owner agreed to pay $200,000 (all but $30,508 suspended) in settlement of allegations it violated federal and state laws by exposing private health information of patients of the Virtua Medical Group when it misconfigured a server, allowing access through the internet without a password. Virtua Medical Group made a separate settlement concerning the data breach in April 2018.
Agency: New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs
New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs

Description: RX 4 Fun and its owner were ordered to pay $277,000 in restitution and civil penalties to resolve multiple violations of the New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act, by failing to provide travel services or products paid for, failing to refund customers, and making misleading statements.
Agency: New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs

Company: Harbor View Restoration Limited Liability Corp.

Agency: New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs

Description: Credit Acceptance Corp., Clover Commercial Corp, and Westlake Financial Services agreed to jointly pay restitution to customers they provided with high interest loans to finance purchases from car dealerships that were accused of deceptive practices. Agency: New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection

Description: Citizens Icon, parent company of 296 entities each operating a parking garage, agreed to pay a $100,000 fine and reimburse $1.2 million to customers who were charged a fee called NYC Living Wage Assessment, which was not related to city laws or used to reach a living wage for employees.
Agency: New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection

Description: Whole Foods agreed to pay $500,000 in settlement of allegations it labeled pre-packaged products with inaccurate prices.
Agency: New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection

Description: Debt collection agency National Credit Adjusters agreed to pay $962,000 restitution and $350,000 fines in settlement of allegations it illegally collected payday loans, used deceptive practices, and threatened legal action it could not take against consumers.

Company: Planet Automotive dba Platinum Auto Mall

Agency: New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection

Agency: New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection

Company: Law Firm of Roni Lynn Deutch

Agency: New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection
Info Source: Settlement reached in NYC lawsuit for advertising of tax services, Associated Press, December 20, 2006 (via Nexis).

Description: Sprint Nextel Corp. agreed to pay New York City $295,000 to settle a lawsuit in which the Department of Consumer Affairs accused the cellular telephone provider of misleading consumers with deceptive advertisements.
Agency: New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection
Info Source: Sprint Nextel pays $295,000 to settle NYC suit for deceptive ads, Associated Press, April 18, 2006 (via Nexis).

Description: T-Mobile USA Inc. paid New York City $135,000 to settle a lawsuit in which the Department of Consumer Affairs accused the cellular telephone provider of misleading consumers with deceptive advertisements.
Agency: New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection
Info Source: T-Mobile settles ad lawsuit, Newsday, December 15, 2005 (via Nexis).

Company: MLB Advanced Media and Steiner Sports Memorabilia, Inc.
Description: The company behind major league baseball's website and a sports memorabilia firm reached a $232,000 settlement with New York City over an allegedly deceptive e-mail promotion, agreeing to cover the cost of refurbishing a Manhattan Little League field.
Agency: New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection
Info Source: New York reaches $232,000 settlement with MLB, memorabilia dealer, Associated Press, April 9, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: violation of law banning sale of dark-colored toy guns
Agency: New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection

Description: Tax preparer Jackson Hewitt Inc. agreed to a settlement, including a $125,000 fine, of allegations that it played a part in deceptively promoting high-interest loans to clients anticipating income tax refunds.
Agency: New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection
Info Source: Tax preparer settles, Newsday, March 2, 2004 (via Nexis).

Description: The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs announced a $600,000 settlement with an Ozone Park-based real estate company that allegedly bilked dozens of unsophisticated home buyers.
Agency: New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection
Info Source: Home Buyers Settlement, Newsday, May 22, 2003 (via Nexis).

Description: Tax return preparer H&R Block agreed to pay $4 million to settle allegations of engaging in deceptive trade practices involving more than 61,000 low-income customers.
Agency: New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection
Info Source: H&R Block to pay $4 million for deceptive practices, consumer commish says, Associated Press, December 12, 2002 (via Nexis).

Agency: Wisconsin Department of Agriculture, Trade and Consumer Protection

Description: Wisconsin O'Connor Corp. agreed to pay $500,000 in restitution, civil penalties, and costs in settlement of allegations it security deposit deductions and rental agreement provisions that were illegal when renting to tenants.
Agency: Wisconsin Department of Agriculture, Trade and Consumer Protection

Description: Sprint agreed to pay $280,000 in settlement of allegations it did not give adequate notice of price increases and changes to service.
Agency: Wisconsin Department of Agriculture, Trade and Consumer Protection

Description: DIRECTV agreed to pay $292,500 in settlement of allegations it made inadequate disclosures of price increases to customers who could have cancelled their contract without a termination fee due to the increase.
Agency: Wisconsin Department of Agriculture, Trade and Consumer Protection

Company: The Timeshare Group, Inc. and The Timeshare Company, LLC.
Description: The Timeshare Group, Inc., The Timeshare Company, LLC and their owner agreed to pay $145,000 in settlement of allegations they violated state law in marketing and selling of timeshare services.
Agency: Wisconsin Department of Agriculture, Trade and Consumer Protection

Description: The Department of Financial Services entered into consent orders with six life insurance companies to resolve alleged violations of New York Insurance Regulations in deferred to immediate annuity replacement transactions.  The insurers, collectively, agreed  to pay $1,152,154 in restitution and $673,000 in penalties.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: The Guardian Insurance & Annuity Company, Inc.
Description: The Department of Financial Services entered into consent orders with six life insurance companies to resolve alleged violations of New York Insurance Regulations in deferred to immediate annuity replacement transactions.  The insurers, collectively, agreed  to pay $1,152,154 in restitution and $673,000 in penalties.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services entered into consent orders with six life insurance companies to resolve alleged violations of New York Insurance Regulations in deferred to immediate annuity replacement transactions. Description: The Department of Financial Services entered into consent orders with six life insurance companies to resolve alleged violations of New York Insurance Regulations in deferred to immediate annuity replacement transactions.
