Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: American Progressive Life and Health Insurance Company of New York
Description: The Department of Financial Services fined American Progressive Life and Health Insurance Company of New York $260,000 for rescinding certain life insurance policies without the consent of policyholders.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services entered into a settlement with student loan servicer Tuition Options LLC and its parent company, EDvantage LLC, under which the companies agreed to pay a $203,000 civil penalty and $33,309 in disgorgement to resolve an investigation of whether Tuition Options engaged in the business of a sales finance company without a license.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: Globe Life Insurance Company of New York
Description: The New York State Department of Financial Services fined Globe Life Insurance Company of New York $439,000 after the company improperly denied claims and rescinded life insurance policies for 439 deceased policyholders and engaged in unfair claims settlement practices in violation of New York Insurance Law.  The policies had a face amount of approximately $7,330,000 and were marketed to low- and middle-income New Yorkers for funeral, burial and other final expenses.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services entered into a consent order with MetLife Insurance Company, under which the insurer agereed to pay a penalty of $19,750,000 for violations of New York Insurance Law stemming from a DFS examination which found that the insurer failed to properly locate and pay benefits to thousands of New York insureds and beneficiaries. As part of the consent order, MetLife also agreed to pay retroactive benefits to policyholders in New York State and elsewhere totaling more than $189 million.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services fined Arch Insurance Company $1 million and National Union Fire Insurance Company $1.2 million and ordered the insurers to provide a combined $8 million in retroactive rebates for violations of New York Insurance Law following an investigation that found both insurers failed to satisfy required minimum loss ratio standards in blanket accident and health insurance policies issued to hundreds of New York volunteer firefighter districts, departments and companies. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay in rebates. Here we assume the total was equally divided between them.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services fined Arch Insurance Company $1 million and National Union Fire Insurance Company $1.2 million and ordered the insurers to provide a combined $8 million in retroactive rebates for violations of New York Insurance Law following an investigation that found both insurers failed to satisfy required minimum loss ratio standards in blanket accident and health insurance policies issued to hundreds of New York volunteer firefighter districts, departments and companies. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay in rebates. Here we assume the total was equally divided between them.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Aetna Health Inc., Aetna Health Insurance Company of New York and Aetna Life Insurance Company were fined $1,950,000 for violations including the failure to make prospective determinations, including pre-authorizations, and failure to acknowledge and respond to member complaints within required timeframes.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Oscar Insurance Corp. was fined $576,950 for violations including the failure to adhere to deadlines for utilization reviews and failure to include detailed explanations of adverse determination notices.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: National Integrity Life Insurance Company agreed to pay a $240,000 civil monetary penalty for violations of New York Insurance Regulations that govern practices for replacing deferred annuity contracts with immediate annuity contracts.  In addition, National Integrity agreed to make restitution to individual consumers affected by its former replacement practices.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Sentinel Insurance Company agreed to pay $1.7 million in restitution and $150,000 in fines to resolve allegations that it overcharged New York policyholders.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Selective Insurance Companies agreed to pay $4.1 million in restitution and $550,000 in fines to resolve allegations that it overcharged New York policyholders.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: American Family Life Assurance Company of New York (AFLAC)
Description: The Department of Financial Services entered into a consent order with American Family Life Assurance Company of New York (AFLAC), which agreed to provide restitution totaling $961,478 to New York consumers for failing to include disclosure language on premium notices in violation of New York Insurance Law and for failing to provide applicants full and clear information related to the replacement of their existing life insurance so that they could make a decision in his or her own best interest.  The insurer also paid a civil penalty of $176,890 for these violations and others discovered during a DFS market conduct examination.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Transamerica paid restitution of $582,436 to New York policyholders and paid a civil penalty of $762,700 for insurance violations relating to disclosure and other practices.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: Athene Life Insurance Company of New York
Description: Athene Life Insurance Company of New York entered into a consent order with the Department of Financial Services under which it agreed to pay a fine of $15 million after DFS found that Athene did not provide required information to about 15,000 policyholders, including premium notices, annual reports or cash surrender value notices, and annual privacy notices from 2015 to 2017.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: First Allmerica Financial Life Insurance Company
Description: FAFLIC agreed to make remedial efforts totaling approximately $40 million for violations of New York insurance Law and regulations.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Chubb Ltd. and Chubb's subsidiary, Illinois Union Insurance Company, agreed to pay a $1.3 million fine as part of a consent order with the Department of Financial Services for underwriting the National Rifle Association-branded Carry Guard insurance program, through Lockton Affinity, in violation of New York Insurance Law.  A DFS investigation found the NRA Carry Guard insurance program unlawfully provided liability insurance to gun owners for acts of intentional wrongdoing, and improperly provided legal services insurance for costs and expenses, for any act of self-defense covered under the policy for gun owners and their resident family members who may be charged with a crime involving a legally possessed firearm.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services fined William Penn Life Insurance Company $6.3 million for engaging in improper reinsurance transactions in an effort to minimize reserves backing life insurance policies issued by the company.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Lockton Cos., LLC and its affiliate Lockton Affinity, LLC agreed to pay a $7 million fine as part of a consent order with the Department of Financial Services for serving as the administrator of the National Rifle Association-branded Carry Guard insurance program, through Lockton Affinity, in violation of New York Insurance Law.  The announcement followed a DFS investigation that found the NRA Carry Guard program unlawfully provided liability insurance to gun owners for certain acts of intentional wrongdoing, and improperly provided insurance coverage for criminal defense for any act of self-defense covered under the policy for gun owners and their resident family members who may be charged with a crime involving a firearm.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services fined Nationstar Mortgage LLC $5 million for violations of New York State Banking Law, stemming from the company's failure to develop effective, scalable controls that could keep pace with its rapid growth. As a result of DFS examinations, Nationstar made restitution of $7 million to New York borrowers.  Under the consent order with DFS, Nationstar also agreed to donate $5 million in residential real property or first-lien mortgages to one or more non-profit organizations to assist in the rehabilitation of vacant and abandoned properties.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services fined QBE Insurance Corp. $750,000 for unlawfully issuing accident-only policies to institutions of higher education in New York to cover their enrolled students.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services entered into a consent order with Clements & Company, two Lloyd's of London syndicates managed by Tokio Marine Kiln Syndicates Limited and Beazley Furlonge Limited, and the United Nations Federal Credit Union (UNFCU) for offering, marketing and underwriting an unlicensed credit and debit card-based life insurance program for UNFCU members.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services entered into a consent order with Clements & Company, two Lloyd's of London syndicates managed by Tokio Marine Kiln Syndicates Limited and Beazley Furlonge Limited, and the United Nations Federal Credit Union (UNFCU) for offering, marketing and underwriting an unlicensed credit and debit card-based life insurance program for UNFCU members.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: Tokio Marine Kiln Syndicates Limited and Beazley Furlonge Limited
Description: The Department of Financial Services entered into a consent order with Clements & Company, two Lloyd's of London syndicates managed by Tokio Marine Kiln Syndicates Limited and Beazley Furlonge Limited, and the United Nations Federal Credit Union (UNFCU) for offering, marketing and underwriting an unlicensed credit and debit card-based life insurance program for UNFCU members.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: Cigna Health and Life Insurance Company
Description: The Department of Financial Services fined Cigna Health and Life Insurance Company $2 million for violations of New York State Insurance Law involving the illegal sale of stop-loss insurance and unapproved health insurance policies that would otherwise have been part of New York's small-group market.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: Total Account Recovery, LLC and E-Finance Call Center Support
Description: The Department of Financial Services entered into a consent order with Total Account Recovery LLC, a payday loan debt collector, and E-Finance Call Center Support, a payday loan servicer, which agreed to provide $11,813,745 in loan forgiveness for New York consumers, to pay a $45,000 penalty, and to cease their activities in New York, where payday loans are illegal.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: MVP Health Plan Inc. and MVP Health Insurance Company
Description: The Department of Financial Services fined MVP Health Plan Inc. and MVP Health Insurance Company $200,000 for incorrectly applying cost-sharing to members' claims and improperly denying some claims for preventive healthcare services.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Excellus Health Plans, Inc. was fined $1 million by the Department of Financial Services for violations of New York insurance law after an investigation found that the insurer wrongly denied contraceptive coverage due to internal system and process errors, failed to promptly pay or deny claims, and failed to acknowledge or resolve consumer grievances within time frames required by law.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: YourPeople Inc. dba Zenefits FTW Insurance Services
Description: YourPeople Inc., doing business as Zenefits FTW Insurance Services, agreed to pay a $1.2 million fine following an investigation by the Department of Financial Services that found repeated violations of insurance law, including allowing unlicensed employees to solicit, negotiate and sell insurance policies.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Lincoln Financial Group paid $50.7 million in restitution to policyholders and a $1.5 million fine for lost insurance claims and for unfair claims settlement practices.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: Oxford Health Plans (NY) Inc. and Oxford Health Insurance, Inc.
Description: Oxford Health Plans (NY) Inc. and Oxford Health Insurance, Inc. were fined $1 million by the Department of Financial Services for improper payments to an unlicensed producer and for failing to respond to consumer grievances within required timeframes in violation of New York State insurance law.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The New York State Department of Financial Services fined Columbian Mutual Life Insurance Company $257,000 after it improperly denied coverage and rescinded life insurance policies for 257 deceased policy holders.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services entered into a consent order with Future Income Payments, LLC  and its owner requiring them to return ill-gotten funds to consumers and pay a $500,000 fine while banning them from engaging in all consumer-related transactions within New York State and with any New York resident. The action was taken after a DFS investigation found the company intentionally misrepresented the transactions which involved pensioners borrowing lump sum payments in exchange for some or all of their monthly pension benefits.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: National Credit Adjusters, LLC agreed to discharge more than $2.26 million in consumer debt on illegal payday loans and provide refunds totaling $724,577 to more than 3,000 New Yorkers.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Webcollex agreed to discharge $52,941 in consumer debt on illegal payday loans and provide refunds totaling $66,129.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Blue Global LLC, an online payday loan lead generator, agreed to pay a $1 million penalty, cease payday loan activities in New York, and provide new consumer warnings and disclosures.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: HealthNow New York Inc. agreed to pay a $750,000 fine for violating New York State regulations with respect to its small group policy renewal program.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: New Day Financial LLC dba New Day USA
Description: New Day Financial LLC dba New Day USA agreed to pay a $1 million penalty to the New York State Department of Financial Services and surrender its mortgage banker's license to do business in New York after its employees, including senior managers, were alleged to have engaged in a widespread scheme to cheat on state-required continuing education courses and exams, among other violations of New York Law.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: Interactiv Education, LLC dba Direct Student Aid, Inc.
Description: Interactiv Education, LLC dba Direct Student Aid, Inc. agreed to pay a $10,000 penalty and wind down and cease its operations nationwide after an investigation by the Department of Financial Services uncovered that the company engaged in misleading and deceptive advertising, and other improper practices.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Selling Source dba MoneyMutual agreed to pay a $2.1 million penalty, cease its payday loan lead generation activities in New York, and provide new consumer warnings and disclosures after a Department of Financial Services investigation uncovered that the company marketed illegal, online payday loans to New York consumers.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Wells Fargo Bank agreed to pay a $2 million penalty and provide approximately $2 million in direct consumer restitution for credit card violations uncovered by a Department of Financial Services.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services announced a Final Consent Judgment to settle its lawsuit against Condor Capital Corporation, a subprime auto lender based in Long Island, which had been accused of retaining millions of dollars owed to vulnerable borrowers and overcharging them for interest in violation of the Truth in Lending Act.  Condor agreed to make full restitution plus nine percent interest to all aggrieved customers nationwide (an estimated $8-9 million), pay a $3 million penalty, and admit to violations of New York and federal law.  Following a sale of its remaining loans in a manner that ensures appropriate consumer protections, Condor was to surrender its licenses in all states.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: AIG was penalized $35 million for Insurance Law and other violations related to its former subsidiaries ALICO and DelAm after a New York State Department of Financial Services investigation uncovered that those subsidiaries solicited insurance business in New York without a license and made intentional misrepresentations and omissions to the Department about those activities.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Narragansett Bay Insurance Company was penalized $327,400 for failing to perform timely inspections of Superstorm Sandy damage claims as required by New York Insurance Law and regulations.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Aetna Life Insurance Company was penalized $500,000 for repeatedly using policy forms that violated New York Insurance Law for certain group life insurance policies and failed to inform policyholders of the rights and benefits guaranteed under those policies.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services announced that MetLife would pay a $50 million penalty for Insurance Law and other violations at its subsidiaries ALICO and DelAm, which it acquired from AIG in 2010. An investigation uncovered that those subsidiaries solicited insurance business in New York without a license and made intentional misrepresentations and omissions to DFS about those activities.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services announced that AXA Equitable would pay a $20 million fine for violations stemming from an investigation that uncovered that it made changes to certain variable annuity products limiting the potential returns for existing customers without providing adequate notice to DFS.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The car-sharing service RelayRides was fined $200,000 for false advertising, unlicensed insurance activity, and other violations.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: American Progressive Life and Health Insurance Company of New York
Description: Four insurers agreed to pay a total of $2.2 million in restitution to 3,475 New York seniors from across the state for overcharging them on Medicare supplemental insurance policies in violation of New York law.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Four insurers agreed to pay a total of $2.2 million in restitution to 3,475 New York seniors from across the state for overcharging them on Medicare supplemental insurance policies in violation of New York law.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: First United American Life Insurance Company
Description: Four insurers agreed to pay a total of $2.2 million in restitution to 3,475 New York seniors from across the state for overcharging them on Medicare supplemental insurance policies in violation of New York law.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Zurich American Insurance Company agreed to refund $4.56 million to policyholders of its New York statutory disability insurance policies because the insurer failed to spend at least 60 percent of total premiums on claims, as required under law.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: QBE agreed to pay $10 million and adopt reforms in its force-placed insurance practices in a settlement with the Department of Financial Services.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Assurant agreed to pay $14 million and adopt reforms in its force-placed insurance practices in a settlement with the Department of Financial Services.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: HealthNow New York Inc. was fined $700,000 for failing to explain coverage and benefit rights to certain health plan members and for failing to tell members how to appeal claims denials.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Oxford Health was fined $665,000 for failing to explain coverage to health plan members and failing to tell them how to challenge claims denials.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services fined a group of insurance companies a total of $2.7 million for failing to notify small businesses that they were eligible to buy special insurance coverage for mental illnesses and children with serious emotional disturbances.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services fined Excellus Health Plan Inc. $995,000 for improperly denying 166 emergency room claims and for failing to explain coverage to consumers in 337,689 instances.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services announced that approximately 300,000 people who bought mass-marketed accidental death and dismemberment insurance policies were being credited $24 million by Hartford Life Insurance because the company didn't comply with the 60 percent minimum loss ratio (MLR) required under New York law.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: New York State authorities ordered 11 insurance companies to refund a total of $114.5 million to holders of policies that covered 573,748 people who were overcharged for health insurance premiums in 2010.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services fined Applied Underwriters $3 million for offering workers' compensation insurance bundled with side agreements called Reinsurance Participation Agreements that were not filed with or approved by the Department.  Under these side agreements many employers, including small businesses, paid substantially more than what would have been paid under similar workers' compensation plans.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: In 2006 Koch Industries paid a fine of $75,000 and signed a consent decree with the Federal Communications to resolve charges that the company's applications for private radio licenses failed to mention that it had been convicted of felonies on three occasions in federal and state courts. Walgreen agreed to pay $7.5 million to the district attorneys of Alameda County and Santa Clara County to settle a case involving the employment of an unlicensed pharmacist.
The district attorneys of Alameda, Los Angeles, Napa and Sonoma counties settled a civil consumer protection action against Fashion Nova, Inc. for $1.75 million.

A task force of local prosecutors, including the Los Angeles Copunty District Attorney, the Santa Monica City Attorney and Santa Barbara County District Attorney won a judgment ordering Box to pay $274,000 for automatically renewing customer payments without their express prior consent as required by federal and state law.

Company: Direct Wines, Inc., and Wine Awesomeness, LLC
Description: The Los Angeles, San Diego, Santa Clara and Santa Cruz county district attorney's offices and the Santa Monica City Attorney announced a settlement in which Direct Wines and Wine Awesomeness agreed to pay $365,000 and make changes in their business practices to resolve allegations that they automatically renewed membership subscriptions, in violation of state law.

Time Warner Cable agreed to pay $18.8 million in a settlement with the district attorneys of Los Angeles, San Diego and Riverside counties of allegations that it used misleading advertising practices to lure consumers to pay for high-speed internet services the company could not deliver.

In a judgment BevMo was ordered to pay $347,034 in a case brought by the district attorneys of Riverside, San Diego, Santa Barbara, and Santa Clara counties based on allegations that customers in the company's stores were being charged higher prices than those listed in advertisements.

PayPal Charitable Giving Fund, Inc. agreed to pay $200,000 as part of the settlement of multistate litigation designed to ensure that donors receive adequate information and disclosures when making charitable contributions through the company's online fundraising platform.
